{{use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox royalty | image = PBandarBinKhalidAlFaisalJI1.jpg | caption = Prince Bandar bin Khalid Al Faisal (2007) | spouse = Nouf bint Mohammed bin Abdullah bin Mohammed Al Saud | issue =Prince Khalid
Princess Loulouwah
Prince Faisal
Princess Haya | full name = Bandar bin Khalid bin Faisal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud | styles = | succession = | reign = | reign-type = | predecessor = | house = [[House of Saud]] | father = [[Khalid bin Faisal Al Saud|Khalid Al Faisal]] | mother = Al Anoud bint Abdullah bin Mohammad bin Abdul Rahman Al Saud | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1965}} | birth_place = | religion = [[Hanbali]] [[Sunni Islam]] }} '''Bandar bin Khalid Al Faisal Al Saud/''' Bandar bin Khalid bin Faisal Al Saudi is a Saudi businessman and a member of [[House of Saud]]. He is chairman of ''[[Al-Watan (Saudi Arabia)|Al Watan]]'', a reformist newspaper. ==Early life== Bandar bin Khalid was born in 1965.{{cite web|title=Bandar Khalid al Faisal|url=http://globalbusinessleaders.org/WebPage/LeaderBio.aspx?leaderCd=l009&levelcd=c02r042|work=Global Business Leaders|accessdate=6 April 2012}} He was the eldest son of [[Khalid bin Faisal Al Saud]] and the brother of [[Saud Bin Khalid Al-Faisal|Saud bin Khalid]] and Sultan bin Khalid. Their mother is Al Anoud bint Abdullah bin Mohammad bin Abdul Rahman Al Saud.{{cite web|title=Family Tree of Khalid bin Faisal bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176284|work=Datarabia|accessdate=5 May 2012}}{{cite web|title=10th Anniversary of Effat University|url=http://www.effatuniversity.edu.sa/About/SiteAssets/Pages/President%20office%20Speeches/2009-16%20november%20_10th%20anniversary%20of%20effat%20university.pdf|work=Effat University|accessdate=6 December 2013|date=10 November 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901202103/http://www.effatuniversity.edu.sa/About/SiteAssets/Pages/President%20office%20Speeches/2009-16%20november%20_10th%20anniversary%20of%20effat%20university.pdf|archive-date=1 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Education== Bandar bin Khalid received a computer science degree from [[King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals]] in [[Dhahran]] in 1988. He then continued his education, receiving a master of arts degree in international business management from the Fletcher School of [[Tufts University]] in 2005.{{cite web|title=Who we are|url=http://tuftsalumni.org/who-we-are/alumni-recognition/tufts-notables/arts-media-athletics/|work=Tufts University|accessdate=5 April 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417151117/http://tuftsalumni.org/who-we-are/alumni-recognition/tufts-notables/arts-media-athletics/|archive-date=17 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} He also attended several courses in the field of executive management, and has more than “1000” flight hours.{{cite web|title=Bandar bin Khalid bin Faisal bin Abdulaziz|url=http://www.arabthought.org/en/cv/bandar-bin-khalid-al-faisal-bin-abdul-aziz|work=Arab Thought Foundation|accessdate=2 May 2012|year=2009|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130223151736/http://www.arabthought.org/en/cv/bandar-bin-khalid-al-faisal-bin-abdul-aziz|archive-date=23 February 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Career== Prince Bandar is a businessman, and holds positions in several organizations. The best-known of his business activities is ''Al Watan'' in [[Saudi Arabia]], a daily paper known for its progressive views.{{cite book|author=Lawrence Pintak|title=Global Communication: Theories, Stakeholders, and Trends|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-3030-4|page=303|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=heEppDtfkNoC&pg=PR9|editor=Thomas L. McPhail|accessdate=7 April 2013|chapter=Arab media and the Al Jazeera effect|date=8 March 2010}} Bandar bin Khalid is the chairman of the board of directors of Assir Foundation for publishing and printing, publisher of ''Al Watan'' newspaper.{{cite news|title=Saudi media industry opening up, says Al Watan boss|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/saudi-media-industry-opening-up-says-al-watan-boss-433508.html|accessdate=8 April 2013|work=Arabian Business|date=4 December 2011|agency=Reuters}} He is also the chairman of Investments Enterprises, a holding company with subsidiaries in many sectors.{{cite news|title=H.R.H. Prince Bandar Bin Khalid Al Faisal|url=http://www.weforum.org/young-global-leaders/hrh-prince-bandar-bin-khalid-al-faisal|accessdate=8 April 2013|work=World Economic Forum}} He is co-founder and a member of the board of trustees of the [[Arab Thought Foundation]], which works to promote better understanding between Arabs and the Western world. He is also deputy managing director of the [[King Faisal Foundation]], an internationally active charitable foundation supporting research, education and social welfare. He is also founder and chairman of the board of directors of Alttmir Company Ltd. since 1995. Another of his business activities is [[Sama (airline)|Sama Airlines]], of which he is the founder and chairman. He is also a member of the board of directors of the Arab House for printing and publishing, and Harvey Nichols Riyadh. Additionally, he is a managing director and board member of [[Saudi Aviation Club|the Saudi Aviation Club]].{{cite news|title=Members of Saudi Aviation Club Board of Directors Appointed|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Members+of+Saudi+Aviation+Club+Board+of+Directors+Appointed.-a0230366844|accessdate=6 April 2013|work=Saudi Press Agency|date=30 June 2010|location=Jeddah}} Bandar bin Khalid was appointed vice president of [[Painting and Patronage]] in 2010.{{cite web|title=HRH Prince Bandar bin Khalid Al Faisal appointed Vice President of Painting and Patronage|url=http://www.paintingandpatronage.com/en/news/174-hrh-prince-bandar-bin-khalid-al-faisal-appointed-vice-president-of-painting-a-patronage|work=Painting and Patronage|accessdate=23 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122185043/http://www.paintingandpatronage.com/en/news/174-hrh-prince-bandar-bin-khalid-al-faisal-appointed-vice-president-of-painting-a-patronage|archive-date=22 January 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Bandar is [[Alfaisal University]]'s chief executive and [[Effat University]]'s board member.{{cite web|title=Alfaisal University unveils new website|url=http://campaign.dubib.com/news/22527_alfaisal-university-unveils-new-website#.T7yVQ9ymhfQ|work=Dubib|accessdate=23 May 2012}}{{cite web|title=Board of Founders|url=http://www.effatcollege.edu.sa/About/Pages/Board_of_Founders.aspx|publisher=Effat College|accessdate=4 March 2013}} Additionally, he is the general president of the [[Masjid al-Haram|Grand Mosque]]'s affairs.{{cite news|title=Governor of Makkah washes the Kaaba|url=http://dailymailnews.com/1211/11/FrontPage/index.php?id=4|newspaper=The Daily Mail|accessdate=30 April 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120709070723/http://dailymailnews.com/1211/11/FrontPage/index.php?id=4|archive-date=9 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Personal life== Prince Bandar is married to Nouf bint Mohammed bin Abdullah bin Mohammed Al Saud, with whom he has four children, Khalid, Loulouwah, Faisal, and Haya.{{cite web|title=Family tree of Bandar bin Khalid al Faisal|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176296|work=Datarabia|accessdate=30 March 2012}} ==Awards== Bandar bin Khalid was selected as one of 238 [[Young Global Leaders]] in 2005, chosen from 8000 candidates. The Young Global Leaders met in June 2005 at an inaugural summit in [[Zermatt]], Switzerland, to discuss the development of global strategies and concrete actions "in order to advance towards a better world in the year 2020".{{cite news|title=Young Global Leaders|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2005/05/28/young-global-leaders.html|accessdate=30 April 2012|work=Newsweek|date=28 May 2005}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Bandar bin Khalid Al Saud}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saud, Bandar bin Khalid bin Faisal Al}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian corporate directors]] [[Category:Great-grandsons of Ibn Saud|Bandar bin Khalid]] [[Category:King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Royal Order of Francis I]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian aviators]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy alumni]]

[[File:Bhakta bir singh fiat 1947.jpg|thumb|Bhakta Bir Singh in a Fiat in Kalimpong, ca 1949.]] [[File:Samyak dyah jatra 1952.jpg|thumb|Image of Dipankar Buddha being brought to Bhuikhel, Kathmandu for Samyak in 1952.]] '''Bhakta Bir Singh Tuladhar''' ([[Devanagari]]: भक्तवीरसिंह तुलाधर) (1912 - 1989) was a Nepalese merchant and philanthropist. He held a special [[Samyak]] (सम्यक) ceremony in 1952 when the country was passing through a political crisis, and the Buddhist alms-giving festival became of crucial importance for both sides in the power struggle.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last=|title=Regmi Research Series|page=60 |date=1968 |work=Regmi Research Series, Issues 1-99 |url=https://books.google.com.np/books?ei=RSj-UdCjFcPorQf63YD4DQ&id=8ghDAAAAYAAJ&dq=samyak+1952&q=samyak+1952#search_anchor |location = }}</ref>
==Business in Tibet==
Bhakta Bir Singh was born to father Samyak Singh (also known as Samek Ratna)<ref>{{cite book |last= von Fürer Haimendorf |first=Christoph |date=1966 |title=Caste and Kin in Nepal, India and Ceylon: Anthropological Studies in Hindu-Buddhist Contact Zones |url=https://books.google.com.np/books/about/Caste_and_Kin_in_Nepal_India_and_Ceylon.html?id=dZE9AAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y |publisher=Asia Publishing House |page=128 |accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> and mother Sānu Māyā [[Tuladhar]] in [[Kathmandu]]. The family home was located at Nhyokhā (न्ह्योखा), a neighborhood in the historical section of Kathmandu. He was married to Laxmi Hirā [[Kansakar]], and was popularly known as Bhagat Sāhu.
The Tuladhars owned a business house in [[Lhasa]], and following in the footsteps of his merchant ancestors, Bhakta Bir Singh went to [[Tibet]] to manage the family shop at a young age. He divided his time between Kathmandu, Lhasa and [[Kalimpong]] in India, a trade center and staging point for mule caravans to Tibet.<ref>{{cite book |last=Tuladhar|first=Kamal Ratna|publisher=Lijala & Tisa |year=2011 |page=109 |title=Caravan to Lhasa: A Merchant of Kathmandu in Traditional Tibet |edition=2nd |url= |accessdate=|isbn=99946-58-91-3}}</ref>
==Samyak and the revolution==
Bhakta Bir Singh's father Samyak Singh had made a pledge in 1950 to sponsor a special Samyak next year, and issued invitations to the ceremony, but he died while the preparations were being made. His sons went ahead with the arrangements to hold it as scheduled. However, the Nepalese revolution broke out, and their plans got caught in the middle. Since Samyak requires the presence of the head of state, Bhakta Bir Singh and his brothers were put in a difficult position regarding whom to invite.<ref>{{cite book |last= Gautama |first= Rājeśa |editor-first= |editor-last= |title= Nepali Congress |url= |publisher= Adroit Publishers |date= 2005 |page=367 | isbn=9788187392613}}</ref>
In November 1950, [[Tribhuvan of Nepal|King Tribhuvan]] went into exile in [[New Delhi]], [[India]] in an attempt to bring down the [[Rana dynasty|Rana regime]] which held real power in the country. The Ranas then made his grandson [[Gyanendra of Nepal|Gyanendra]] the king.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nepalresearch.com/history/background/revolution_1950.htm |title= The Revolution of 1950/51 |last= Kraemer |first= Karl-Heinz |date= |website= |publisher= Nepal Research |accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> They pressed Bhakta Bir Singh to hold Samyak with Gyanendra presiding over it in order to grant him cultural endorsement. The freedom fighters, meanwhile, threatened him not to do so. Bhakta Bir Singh found a way out of the dilemma by citing his father's recent death and deferring the event.<ref>{{cite book |last=Tuladhar |first=Daman Raj |editor-first= |editor-last= |title=Contemporary Nepal, 1945-1955 |url=https://books.google.com.np/books?ei=w88MUqHXCsPSrQfzvICoBQ&id=Qe8cAAAAMAAJ&dq=samyak+daya+bir+singh&q=daya+bir+singh#search_anchor |publisher=Laxmi Publications |date=1980 |page=243 |isbn=}}</ref>
The Ranas were overthrown in February 1951, and Tribhuvan returned to Nepal. A year later, the postponed Samyak was held on 15 January 1952 with Tribhuvan presiding over it. A stone [[mandala]] was installed at the venue at [[Bhuikhel]] to commemorate the event.<ref>{{cite book |last= Shakya |first= Hem Raj |publisher= Svayambhu Vikash Mandala |year=2004 |page=617 |title= Sri Svayambhu Mahacaitya |edition=1st |url= |accessdate=|isbn=99933-864-0-5}}</ref> The religious celebration was seen as an affirmation of the king's triumph in the power struggle against the hereditary prime ministers the Ranas.<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |editor-first= Katia |editor-last= Buffetrille |title= Revisiting Rituals in a Changing Tibetan World |url=https://books.google.com.np/books?id=hfAkbA89Lp0C&dq=samyak+tribhuvan&q=232#v=snippet&q=232&f=false |publisher= BRILL |date= 2012 |page=232 | isbn=9789004232174}}</ref>
Samyak commemorates the practice of giving to the Buddhas and monks in the [[Newar Buddhism|Newar Buddhist]] tradition. It is spread over three days, and is held at [[Kathmandu Durbar Square]] and the field at the foot of [[Swayambhu]] hill. During the ceremony, hundreds of images of [[Dīpankara Buddha]] are assembled, and gifts of different types of food are made to the deities and the Buddhist community.<ref>{{cite book |last= Lewis |first= Todd Thornton |authorlink= |title= Popular Buddhist Texts from Nepal: Narratives and Rituals of Newar Buddhism |url= https://books.google.com.np/books?id=pC_XoZsvBuIC&pg=PA225&dq=samyak+nepal&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2uj7UeXdOs2krQfIrIHgCA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=samyak%20nepal&f=false |accessdate=8 August 2013 |year=2000 |publisher= State University of New York Press |location= |isbn= |page=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Todd T. |title=Notes on the Uray and the Modernization of Newar Buddhism |url=http://www.thlib.org/static/reprints/contributions/CNAS_23_01_08.pdf |accessdate=8 August 2013 |newspaper=Contributions to Nepalese Studies |date=January 1996}} Page 112.</ref>
==See also==
* [[Lhasa Newar (trans-Himalayan traders)]] * [[Samyak]]

A '''boilery''' or '''boiling house''' is a place of [[boiling]], much as a [[bakery]] is a place of baking. Boilery can also mean the process and equipment for boiling. Although they are now generally confined to factories, and usually boil industrial products rather than food, historically they were more common in daily life. Boileries are typically for boiling large quantities of fluid.<ref>http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-boilery.htm</ref>
In the 17th to 19th centuries, boileries were used to convert [[sugarcane]] juice into raw [[sugar]]. These boileries were usually sturdy places, built from stone, and contained several copper kettles, each with a furnace beneath it.,<ref>[https://www.geograph.org.uk/photo/2535107 Photo of Beamish Colliery Boiler House]</ref> Sugarcane juice was treated with lime in large clarifying vats, before it was heated in copper kettles over individual furnaces. Due to their importance, many Western sugar plantations had their own boileries on site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/boilery |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302042058/http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Boilery |archivedate=2009-03-02 |df= }}</ref>
Soap would also be made in a boiling house.
Another use for a boilery is to make salt through the evaporation of [[brine]] water.,<ref>[http://www.visitslovakia.com/saltworks-near-presov Saltworks Boilery in Slovakia]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1828-dictionary.com/d/word/boilery |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111101013332/http://1828-dictionary.com/d/word/boilery |archivedate=2011-11-01 |df= }}</ref>

'''Carl-Peter Edmund Moriz Forster'''<ref>{{cite web|author=Stocks |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=788104&ticker=GM |title=Stocks - Bloomberg |publisher=Investing.businessweek.com |date=2017-12-11 |accessdate=2018-02-22}}</ref> (born 9 May 1954, in [[London]]), is an [[England|English]] born [[Germany|German]] [[businessman]]. Forster was the group [[Chief Executive]] of [[Tata Motors]] between January, 2010<ref name="tatamotors.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.tatamotors.com/our_world/press_releases.php?ID%3D516%26action%3DPull |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206041016/http://www.tatamotors.com/our_world/press_releases.php?ID=516&action=Pull |archivedate=2010-12-06 |df= }}</ref> and 9 September 2011.<ref name="BBConC-PFResignation">{{cite web|author=Jorn Madslien |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14859137 |title=Tata Motors chief Carl-Peter Forster resigns - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-02-22}}</ref>
==Biography== Born in London, Forster was raised in London, [[Bonn]] and [[Athens]]. His father was a German [[diplomat]]. Forster holds degrees in Economics from [[Bonn University]], and in Aviation and Space Technology from [[Munich University of Technology]].
===Career=== On graduation in 1982, Forster joined [[McKinsey & Company|McKinsey]] as a consultant in [[Munich]].
===BMW=== In 1986, he joined [[BMW]] where he held various leadership positions before becoming Managing Director of BMW [[South Africa]] in 1996, and the board member responsible for all vehicle development projects in 1999.
===General Motors=== In April 2001, Forster was appointed Chairman and Managing Director of [[Adam Opel AG]]. In June 2004 he became President of GM Europe, based in [[Zurich]], [[Switzerland]], and Chairman of the Opel Supervisory Board. In April 2005 he also became Chairman of [[Saab Automobile|Saab]]. On 1 January 2006, he was additionally appointed [[General Motors]] Group Vice President and a member of the GM Automotive Strategy Board, and took over the role as the senior-ranking executive for [[General Motors|GM]]’s activities in Europe.<ref name=WSJ1>[https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20091106-713409.html GM: Forster To Leave Co; External Search For New Europe CEO]</ref>
On November 3, 2009 General Motors announced that it would retain ownership of its [[Opel]] subsidiary .<ref name=WSJ2>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125728725957326159?mod=WSJ_hpp_LEFTTopStories GM Throws Opel Deal Into Reverse ]</ref> Forster commented about GM’s decision not to sell the units to [[Magna International]]:<ref name=times>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/engineering/article6906710.ece GM Europe president quits following Opel U-Turn]</ref> {{cquote|Such a sudden shift isn’t comprehensible. I hoped that it would have come to a much different outcome}} On 6 November 2009 General Motors confirmed that Forster would be leaving all positions with GM Group globally.<ref name=WSJ1 />
===Tata Motors=== On 15 February 2010 India's [[Tata Motors]] announced that Carl Peter Forster has been appointed as the group CEO with overall responsibility for Tata Motors globally, including that of its British unit [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]] and [[Land Rover]].<ref name="tatamotors.com"/>
Following a surprise announcement on Friday 9 September 2011 it was revealed that Carl-Peter would step down from his group CEO role due to 'unavoidable personal circumstances'. However, he remained on the Tata Motors board of directors in a non-Executive capacity.
===Gordon Murray Design Limited=== Ex-Tata group CEO joined Gordon Murray design house.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonmurraydesign.com/press.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002054535/http://www.gordonmurraydesign.com/press.php |archivedate=2013-10-02 |df= }} Undated press release accessed 27 September 2013</ref>
===Rexam=== In June 2014 it was announced that Forster had been appointed a non-executive director of the UK packaging conglomerate [[Rexam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talent4boards.com/rexam/ |title=Rexam announces Carl-Peter Forster to its Board as Non-Executive Director|date=6 June 2014|publisher=Talent for boards|accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Forster is married and has three children and lives in Oxford.
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Charles Underwood Carpenter''' (1872 - Jan. 15, 1928<ref>"[https://books.google.nl/books?id=IBJbAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA534 Charles U. Carpenter, Obituary]" in ''Princeton Alumni Weekly,'' Vol. 28. (1927/28) p. 534</ref>) was an American business manager, management author, and inventor, known as "one of the earliest advocates of the committee system in factory management."<ref>[[Alfred D. Chandler, Jr.]]. ''Strategy and Structure: Chapters in the History of the American Industrial Enterprise.'' (2003), p. 444</ref>
== Biography == Carpenter got his degree from [[Princeton University]] in 1893, and started his career in industry. He came into prominence after being hired by [[John Henry Patterson (NCR owner)|John Henry Patterson]], founder of the [[National Cash Register Company]] (NCR), in 1901 to reorganize the labor management department of his company.<ref>Paul Bernstein. ''American Work Values: Their Origin and Development.'' 1997. p. 197.</ref> This resulted in the development of the concept of functionalized labour management department, which was set up within NCR. To further promote the idea published the article "The Working of a Labor Department in Industrial Establishments." in the ''[[Engineering Magazine]]'' in 1903.<ref> Bruce E. Kaufman. ''Managing the Human Factor: The Early Years of Human Resource Management in American Industry,'' 2008, p .68.</ref>
At National Cash Register Company (NCR) was put in charge of a workforce of 7.500 man for several years. Around 1905 he left the company and to become President of the Herring-Hall Marvin Safe Company,<ref>[[Jesse Lynch Williams]], Edwin Mark Norris (1906) ''Rapport du Comité consultatif.'' Princeton University. p. 302</ref> the largest safe company in the world.<ref>''[https://books.google.nl/books?id=m2pIAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA236 The Princeton Alumni Weekly],'' jan 6, 1906</ref> Here he wrote the book "Profit Making in Shop and Factory Management," published in 1908.
In the 1910s he joined the Recording and Computing Machines Company, a manufacturer of precision equipment. The Princeton Alumni Weekly in 1918 reported that "Charles U. Carpenter is the Vice-President and Manager of Works, of the Recording and Computing Machines Company of Dayton, Ohio. He has under him 9,000 employees. During the war he gave his big plant over to the manufacture of war supplies. His first job was the production of six million time fuses. He also made many of the optical instruments employed in sighting the guns. An unusual service which he personally rendered the country was the establishment of a training school for mechanics. So important was this work that it has been made the subject of a special bulletin by the Department of Labor, Imperial Munitions Hoard of Canada, and also by the Section on Industrial Training of the Council of National Defence at Washington."<ref>''Princeton Alumni Weekly,'' Vol. 17 (1916), p. 683</ref>
In 1920 Carpenter became president and general manager of the National Industrial Engineering Company, and in those days he was also Vice president of the western Appraisal Company.<ref>''[http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?q1=Carpenter;id=uc1.c2534810;view=image;seq=267;start=1;sz=10;page=search;num=257 Factory and Industrial Management],'' Vol. 59. (1920) p. 148</ref>
== Work == Carpenter was promotor of the American system of manufacturing. He claimed. that "one can but admire the wonderful systems of organization and management by which the enormous business interests of the United States are governed."<ref name="C 02 in S 95">Carpenter (1902), as cited in: [[Yehouda Shenhav]]. "[http://people.socsci.tau.ac.il/mu/yshenhav/files/2013/07/From-Chaos-to-Systems.pdf From Chaos to Systems: The Engineering Foundations of Organization Theory, 1879-1932]," in: ''Administrative Science Quarterly,'' Vol. 40, No. 4 (Dec., 1995)</ref>
He firmly believed in firm principles of management, and started that "if the system of organization is founded upon the correct principles, the perfection of the details will follow as a natural sequence."<ref name="C 02 in S 95"/>
Carpenter was, however, not blind for the all-day practice. He observed, that "in the mind of the old-time manufacturer the word 'system' is indissolubly linked with that of horror of 'extra clerks'..."<ref name="C 02 in S 95"/>
== Selected publications == * Carpenter, Charles Underwood. ''[https://archive.org/details/profitmakinginsh00carp Profit Making in Shop and Factory Management].'' Engineering Magazine, 1908. * Carpenter, Charles Underwood. ''[http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/005715215 Increasing Production, Decreasing Costs],'' Engineering Magazine Company, (1920)

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} <!--- Don't mess with this line! ---><!--- Write your article below this line ---> '''Christopher Michael Jack Gorell Barnes''' (born May 1974) <ref>https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/W_hxJ9Ig1ufBDz2YGQwPkyQ_1OA/appointments</ref> is an English digital entrepreneur and marine conservationist best known as executive producer of the award-winning documentary ''[[The End of the Line: How Overfishing Is Changing the World and What We Eat#Film adaptation|The End of the Line]]''.
==Early life== Gorell Barnes was born to Henry Gorell Barnes (1939-1983),<ref>Gov.uk Probate Record Search, Surname 'Barnes', Year of Death '1984' (n.b. date of death given as 13 November 1983), p. 495</ref> merchant banker and a director of Morgan Grenfell,<ref>Money Market Directory 1982, ed. T. H. Fitzgerald, p. 1105</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/business/london-exchange-entering-new-era.html</ref> and Gillian (née Carruthers), a therapist.<ref>The Sunday Times, Hattie Williams, 13 April 2014 URL= https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/how-i-made-it-chris-gorell-barnes-founder-of-adjust-your-set-9vt3hqn8p7m Date accessed= 27 November 2018</ref><ref>Working with Families, Gill Gorell Barnes, Macmillan, 1984, p. iv</ref> His paternal grandfather was Sir William Lethbridge Gorell Barnes (1909-1987), a [[War Cabinet]] official later of the [[HM Treasury|Treasury]] and [[Colonial Office]] (where he was [[Deputy Under Secretary of State]] from 1959 to 1963), and who had been Personal Assistant to Prime Minister [[Clement Attlee]] from 1946 to 1948.<ref>The Routledge Guide to British Political Archives: Sources since 1945, ed. Chris Cook, Routledge, 2006, p. 13</ref> His paternal great-grandfather was Sir Frederic Gorell Barnes (1856-1939), M.P. for [[Faversham]], Kent from 1895-1900, Assistant Food Commissioner and Commissioner of the Education and Propaganda Branch of the [[Minister of Food|Ministry of Food]] from 1918 to 1921.<ref>Alumni Cantabrigienses, vol. 2- From 1752 to 1900, Part 1: Abbey-Challis, ed. John Venn, J. A. Venn, Cambridge University Press, p. 162</ref> The Gorell Barnes family were of Ashgate House, [[Ashgate, Derbyshire]], with the [[Baron Gorell|Barons Gorell]] descending from Henry, elder brother of Chris Gorell Barnes's ancestor Charles (1818-1886; of Mossley Hill, Lancashire, J.P., a merchant).<ref>Burke's Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage 2003, vol. 2, p. 1597</ref> The politician and colliery owner [[Alfred Barnes (Derbyshire politician)|Alfred Barnes]] was the youngest brother of Henry and Charles.<ref>Obituary - Alfred Barnes", The Times (36625), London, 29 November 1901, p. 6</ref><ref>Armorial Families: A Directory of Gentlemen of Coat Armour, seventh edition, Arthur Charles Fox-Davies, Hurst & Blackett, Ltd, 1929, p. 96</ref>
Gorell Barnes was raised at [[Maida Vale]], and studied at [[Bedales School|Bedales]] and the [[European Business School London|European Business School]] at [[Regent's University London]].<ref>The Sunday Times, Hattie Williams, 13 April 2014 URL= https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/how-i-made-it-chris-gorell-barnes-founder-of-adjust-your-set-9vt3hqn8p7m Date accessed= 27 November 2018</ref><ref>https://www.standard.co.uk/business/markets/chris-gorell-barnes-video-venture-adjust-your-set-is-really-clicking-with-the-big-brands-8708945.html</ref>
==Career== Gorell Barnes founded a digital content agency called Adjust Your Set in 2008.<ref name="Sunday Times">[http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/business/small_business/article1399137.ece Article in ''The Sunday Times'']</ref><ref name="Evening Standard">[https://www.standard.co.uk/business/markets/chris-gorell-barnes-video-venture-adjust-your-set-is-really-clicking-with-the-big-brands-8708945.html Article in ''Evening Standard'']</ref><ref>[http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/business/small_business/article1521199.ece Article in ''The Sunday Times'']</ref> He was named by the ''[[London Evening Standard]]'' newspaper in 2013 as one of the most powerful 'Tech Stars' in the UK.<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/the-power-1000--londons-most-influential-people-2013-tech-stars-8824511.html Article in Evening Standard]</ref> Adjust Your Set was named in [[New Media Age]]'s Top 100 Interactive Agencies 2010 as 'one to watch'<ref>[http://lab.zoho.co.uk/2011/02/13/nma-interactive-agencies-2010ones-to-watch/ Article in New Media Age]</ref> and in 2011 it was named as a winner in the [[Brightcove]] Online Video Innovation Awards. Gorell Barnes has sat on the board of Eagle Eye Solutions, a digital consumerism business, since 2007.<ref>[http://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/prices-and-markets/stocks/new-and-recent-issues/new-recent-issue-details.html?issueId=8972 London Stock Exchange site]</ref> Other board members include [[Terry Leahy|Sir Terry Leahy]], former [[Tesco]] chief executive.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/11720367/Sainsburys-strikes-deal-with-Sir-Terry-Leahy-backed-Eagle-Eye.html Article in ''The Daily Telegraph'']</ref>
Gorell Barnes was executive producer for ''The End of the Line'', a documentary film that changed attitudes towards seafood, including among companies such as [[Pret A Manger]] and [[Marks & Spencer]].<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1191337/End-line-Pret-tuna-sandwich-After-seeing-shock-new-film-food-chain-boss-bans-snacks-containing-endangered-fish.html Article in ''Daily Mail'']</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/jun/08/pret-a-manger-sustainable-tuna-film Article in ''The Guardian'']</ref><ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/news/ms-lines-up-behind-ban-on-r-bluefin-tuna-6773679.html Article in ''London Evening Standard'']</ref> It won the inaugural Puma Creative Impact Award in 2011 for its success in changing consumer behaviour.<ref>[http://creative.puma.com/us/en/2011/10/first-annual-puma-creative-impact-award-gala-for-documentary-film/ Press release on Puma site]</ref><ref>[http://www.screendaily.com/the-end-of-the-line-nets-puma-creative-impact-award/5033190.article Article on Screen Daily website]</ref>
A study by the [[BRITDOC Foundation]] found that it had been seen by more than one million people and had created press and media attention worth more than £4 million.<ref>[http://www.tippingpointfilmfund.com/site/wp-content/uploads/TheEndOfTheLine_EvaluationDocument.pdf The BRITDOC study document]</ref> The film was described by the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' as "an apocalyptic documentary that is as beautiful as it is damning".<ref name="Chicago Tribune">[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2009-07-17/entertainment/0907160463_1_bluefin-tuna-fish-oceans Article in ''Chicago Tribune'']</ref>
==Marine conservation==
In 2009, Gorell Barnes and fellow producer [[George Duffield (film-maker)|George Duffield]] founded a marine conservation charity, the Blue Marine Foundation which aims to create [[marine reserve]]s.<ref name="Sunday Times"/><ref>[http://www.superyachttimes.com/editorial/51/article/id/9966 Article in Superyacht Times]</ref><ref>[http://www.bluemarinefoundation.com/ Blue Marine Foundation website]</ref><ref>[http://www.tatler.com/bystander/events/2015/june/blue-marine-foundation-5th-birthday-party#!/17792/image/3 Article in The Tatler]</ref> In 2010 it brokered a deal that created a huge marine reserve around the [[Chagos Archipelago|Chagos Islands]]<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/nature/billionaire-saves-marine-reserve-plans-2077437.html Article in The Independent]</ref> and two years later one that protected the waters around [[Turneffe Atoll]] in the [[Caribbean]].<ref>[http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/public/searescue/article1167746.ece Article in The Sunday Times]</ref> Among its supporters are [[Helena Bonham Carter]].<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/11407180/Helena-Bonham-Carter-gets-naked-with-giant-tuna.html Article in Daily Telegraph]</ref><ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/helena-bonham-carter-poses-naked-fish-new-campaign-article-1.2111714 Article in New York Daily News]</ref>
==Personal life== Gorell Barnes lives in London with his long-term partner [[Martha Lane Fox, Baroness Lane-Fox of Soho]], co-founder of [[lastminute.com]].<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2664227/Life-inside-crippled-body-web-millionaire-Martha-Lane-Fox.html Article in ''Daily Mail'']</ref> Their identical twin sons, Milo and Felix, were born in 2016.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/05/lastminutecom-founder-martha-lane-fox-becomes-mother-12-years-af</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://adjustyourset.com/ Adjust Your Set site] * [http://www.eagleeye.com/ Eagle Eye Solutions site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120806141355/http://endoftheline.com/ The End of the Line site] * [http://www.bluemarinefoundation.com/ Blue Marine Foundation site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barnes, Chris}}

'''Christian Augustus Henry Allhusen''' (1806–1890) was a [[Danes|Danish]]-[[England|English]] chemical manufacturer based in the North East of England. Born in [[Kiel]] when it was in the Danish Duchy of Holstein, he and his family were displaced when [[Louis-Nicolas Davout|Marshall Davoust]], [[Napoleon]]'s "Iron Marshall," occupied the family home as his headquarters. Allhusen was employed by Koch & Sons, grain merchants of [[Rostock]] and then moved to [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], where he was employed by Campbell & Reveley, also grain merchants.<ref name ="Allen">{{cite book | title = Some Founders of the Chemical Industry: Men to be Remembered | author= John Fenwick Allen | publisher = Sherratt & Hughes | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1GYoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA234&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiThfTx4PHbAhUDOKwKHdFEDLIQ6AEINDAD#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1906 | pages = 231 - 248 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref> Allhusen became a British citizen by a private Act of Parliament.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Parliamentary Debates (Authorized Edition), Volume 30 | author= | publisher = Wyman| location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ky9VAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT1&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwju0NLn8vHbAhVGL6wKHegaBlk4ChDoAQhVMAk#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1835 | page = | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref> He later went into partnership with [[Henry Bolckow]] and expanded into the ship and insurance brokerage business.<ref name = "Allen"/><ref name ="Joseph">{{cite book | title = The Navigation Laws of Great Britain, Historically and Practically Considered, with Reference to Commercial and National Defence | author= Joseph ALLEN (of Greenwich Hospital.) | publisher = Baily Bros. & James Ridgway | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iPYVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA114&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKqtm1-PHbAhVPeawKHZeUDm44HhDoAQhWMAk#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1849 | pages = 107 - 112 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref><ref name ="Reid">{{cite book | title = Middlesbrough and Its Jubilee: A History of the Iron and Steel Industries, with Biographies of Pioneers | author= Sir Hugh Gilzean-Reid | publisher = "The Gazette" Printing and Publishing Offices | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iPYVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA114&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKqtm1-PHbAhVPeawKHZeUDm44HhDoAQhWMAk#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1881 | pages = 113 - 114 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref>
In 1840, Allhusen purchased a soap works in [[Gateshead]], and began the manufacture of chemicals, eventually calling the company C. Allhusen & Sons. In 1871, Allhusen converted his enterprise into a [[joint-stock company]], Newcastle Chemical Works, Ltd. He made a large fortune, and was influential in the region as company director and shareholder in such companies as the Northumberland & Durham District Bank, the Newcastle & Gates Water Company and the Consett Iron Works. He was an active member of the Newcastle Chamber of Commerce and the Tyne Commission.<ref name = Allen/>
In 1854, Allhusen was among local industrialists urging construction of a new [[Wharf|quay]] for Gateshead. When the quay was eventually constructed, the local government failed to include necessary transportation facilities to allow efficient transport to and from the quay facility. As a result, the quay complex required years of subsidies and struggled to avoid failure as Allhusen had predicted.<ref>{{cite book | title = North East England, 1850-1914: The Dynamics of a Maritime-industrial Region | author= Graeme J. Milne| publisher = Boydell Press | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wbkV5FL8ygAC&pg=PA96&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwifjuSZ8PHbAhVIZKwKHSq2BHMQ6AEIVDAJ#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false| date = 2006 | page = 96 | isbn = 9781843832409 | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref>
Allhusen died January 13, 1890 at Stoke Court, [[Buckinghamshire]].<ref>{{cite book | title = Chemist and Druggist, Volume 36 | author= | publisher = Benn Brothers | location= |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=alU9AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA61&dq=Christian+Allhusen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwju0NLn8vHbAhVGL6wKHegaBlk4ChDoAQgmMAA#v=onepage&q=Christian%20Allhusen&f=false | date = 1890 | page = 61 | isbn = | accessdate = 26 June 2018 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==See also== *''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Allhusen, Christian Augustus Henry (1806–1890), chemical manufacturer by N. G. Coley, rev.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Allhusen, Christian Augustus Henry}}

''[[Diario AS]]'' | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://cincodias.com/ ''Cinco Días''] }} '''''Cinco Días''''' (meaning ''Five Days'' in English) is a [[Spanish language|Spanish]] business and finance newspaper published in [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]. Founded in 1978 it is the oldest business newspaper in the country.{{cite web|title=Cinco Días|url=http://www.voxeurop.eu/en/content/source-information/1122591-cinco-dias|work=VoxEurope|accessdate=26 November 2014}} ==History and profile== ''Cinco Días'' was first published in March 1978.{{cite web|title=National newspapers in Spain|url=http://www.spain-newspaper.com/newspapers.htm|publisher=Spain Newspapers|accessdate=26 November 2014}}{{cite web|title=Cinco Días celebrates issue number 10,000|url=http://www.prisa.com/en/sala-de-prensa/cinco-dias-celebrates-issue-number-10-000/|work=Prisa Group|accessdate=26 November 2014|date=6 February 2013}} The reason behind the establishment of this business paper was related to the [[Oil crisis of 1973|oil crisis]] experienced in the country in the mid-1970s. Because due to this crisis the Spanish society became more interested in [[macro economics]] and labor-related problems. ''Cinco Días'' is published in tabloid format five times per week from Monday to Friday and is based in [[Madrid]].{{cite journal|author1=Ally Palmer|author2=Terry Watson|title=The secrets of good design|journal=Strategy Report|date=June 2004|volume=3|issue=3|url=http://ideas.typepad.com/WANreport.pdf|accessdate=6 February 2015}} In 1989 the paper became owned by the [[PRISA|Prisa Group]]{{cite journal|author1=Esteban Romero-Frías|author2=Liwen Vaughan|title=Exploring the Relationships Between Media and Political Parties Through web Hyperlink Analysis: The Case of Spain|journal=Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology|date=2012|volume=63|issue=5|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/asi.22625/abstract|accessdate=18 December 2014|doi=10.1002/asi.22625|pages=967–976}} which is also the owner of ''[[El País]]'' and ''[[Diario AS]]''.{{cite web|title=Prisa Noticias|url=http://www.prisanoticias.com/en/pagina/cinco-dias/|work=Prisa Group|accessdate=26 November 2014}}{{cite journal|author1=Enric Castelló|author2=David Domingo|title=Spanish media facing new media: a challenge to journalists?|journal=International Journal of Iberian Studies|date=2005|volume=18|issue=3|url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=c38d19e1-7bac-4754-8a34-a4d204a334c8%40sessionmgr4002&vid=0&hid=4210|accessdate=3 December 2014}}{{cite web|author=David Ward|title=A Mapping Study of Media Concentration and Ownership in Ten European Countries|url=http://77.87.161.246/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/A-Mapping-Study-of-Media-Concentration-and-Ownership-in-Ten-European-Countries.pdf|work=Dutch Media Authority|accessdate=11 February 2015|year=2004}} The publisher of ''Cinco Días'' is Estructura, a subsidiary of Prisa Group.{{cite web|author1=Jose L. Alvarez|author2=Carmelo Mazza|author3=Jordi Mur|title=The management publishing industry in Europe|url=http://www.iese.edu/research/pdfs/OP-99-04-E.pdf|work=University of Navarra|accessdate=27 April 2015|format=Occasional Paper No:99/4|date=October 1999|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100630042406/http://www.iese.edu/research/pdfs/OP-99-04-E.pdf|archivedate=30 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Specialised and local press|url=http://www.prisa.com/upload/ficheros/cuentas-anuales/memoria2001_en/unidades/prensa.html|work=Grupo PRISA|accessdate=10 August 2015|format=Annual Report|date=2002|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304185457/http://www.prisa.com/upload/ficheros/cuentas-anuales/memoria2001_en/unidades/prensa.html|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} ''Cinco Días'' has various supplements{{cite book|author1=Sandra Truscott|author2=Maria Garcia|title=Dictionary of Contemporary Spain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LMp8RsxuU0cC&pg=PA65|accessdate=26 November 2014|date=12 November 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-59509-7|page=65}} and includes a section for articles from ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.{{cite web|title=Communication|url=http://www.bid-org.com/comunication/|work=Business Initiative Directories|accessdate=26 November 2014}} The paper has a [[left-liberal]] stance.{{cite web|title=Model bailout for Spain's banks|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/home/debatten/links-2012-06_spain/|work=Eurotopics|accessdate=26 November 2014|date=15 November 2013}} ==Circulation and readership== ''Cinco Días'''s circulation was 21,623 copies in 1994. The circulation of the paper was 28,000 copies in 2001{{cite journal|title=Financial Newspapers|journal=SFN Flash|date=7 January 2004|volume=7|issue=1|url=http://www.wan-press.org/IMG/pdf/04Q_03_SFN_Flash_FullText-2.pdf|accessdate=17 February 2015}} and 24,621 copies in 2002.{{cite web|title=Printed Media Group (GMI)|url=http://www.prisa.com/upload/ficheros/cuentas-anuales/memoria2002_en/unidades_prensa.html|publisher=Grupo PRISA|accessdate=10 August 2015|format=Annual report|date=2003|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304193839/http://www.prisa.com/upload/ficheros/cuentas-anuales/memoria2002_en/unidades_prensa.html|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} The paper had a circulation of 25,041 copies on weekdays in 2003, and it rose to 29,333 copies on weekdays in 2004.{{cite web|title=Spain: New circulation figures 2007|url=http://www.adnative.net/en/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=22678&title=spain-new-circulation-figures-2007newspapers#.VKRRsmSsXRB|work=Publicitas|accessdate=31 December 2014|date=13 May 2008}} The circulation of the paper increased to 30,425 copies in 2005.{{cite web|author=Ramón Salaverría|date=2007|title=The Spanish Media Landscape|url=http://dadun.unav.edu/bitstream/10171/36289/1/Spanish_media_landscape__Salaverria.pdf|work=European Media Governance|publisher=Intellect Books Ltd|isbn=978-1-84150-192-5|page=279|accessdate=24 April 2015|format=Book chapter}} In 2006 its readership was 30%, making it the fifth most read business paper among Spanish men.{{cite book|author=Craig Carroll|title=Corporate Reputation and the News Media: Agenda-setting Within Business News Coverage in Developed, Emerging, and Frontier Markets|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F2iNAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA176|accessdate=26 November 2014|date=1 September 2010|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-25244-1|page=176}} Its circulation rose to 33,997 copies in 2006 and to 40,554 copies in 2007. The paper had a circulation of 40,554 copies in 2008.{{cite book|author=Angel Arrese et. al.|editor=Alan B. Albarran|title=The Handbook of Spanish Language Media|date=2009|publisher=Rouledge|location=New York|url=http://dadun.unav.edu/handle/10171/20819|accessdate=28 April 2015|chapter=The Media in Spain}} Its circulation was 40,000 copies in 2011. ==See also== *[[List of newspapers in Spain]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://cincodias.com/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cinco Dias}} [[Category:1978 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:Business newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Madrid]] [[Category:Daily newspapers published in Spain]] [[Category:PRISA]] [[Category:Publications established in 1978]] [[Category:Spanish-language newspapers]]

'''Lucinda "Cindy" Lee Gallop''' (born 1 February 1960)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.dellam.com/english/FI/FITZGERALD%20SHUREY%20TARBUCK%20LLP.html |title=FITZGERALD SHUREY TARBUCK LLP |work=Dellam Corporate Information Ltd. |year=2013 |accessdate=12 June 2013}}</ref> is an English advertising consultant, founder and former chair of the US branch of advertising firm [[Bartle Bogle Hegarty]], and founder of the IfWeRanTheWorld and MakeLoveNotPorn companies.<ref name="forbes">{{cite web|last=Bradshaw|first=Leslie|title=How Cindy Gallop Broke Through the 'Thick Layer of Men' and Became the Counterpoint to Porn|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lesliebradshaw/2011/08/10/how-cindy-gallop-broke-through-the-thick-layer-of-men-and-became-the-counterpoint-to-porn/|work=Forbes|accessdate=25 April 2012|date=8 October 2011}}</ref> According to the TED blog, Gallop's TEDTalk "Make Love Not Porn" was one of the "most talked about presentations" at the 2009 TED conference.<ref name="tedtalks">{{cite web|title=Cindy Gallop: Make Love Not Porn|url=http://blog.ted.com/2009/12/02/cindy_gallop_ma/|publisher=TED|accessdate=26 April 2012|date=2 December 2009}}</ref> She lives in New York City.<ref name="forbes" />
==Early life== Cindy Gallop was born in [[Amersham]], Buckinghamshire, and grew up in [[Brunei]]. She is of half English, half Chinese descent. Gallop's father is English and her mother Malaysian Chinese, from Alor Star in Kedah. Her parents live in Penang, where she returns regularly.
Gallop studied English Literature at [[Somerville College]], [[Oxford University]], receiving an MA in English Language and Literature, followed by an MA from [[Warwick University]] in Theatre of the European Renaissance.<ref name="forbes" />
==Career== Gallop worked as a theatre publicist and marketer in England for several years before switching careers to advertising.<ref name="tedblog">{{cite web |title=Q&A with Cindy Gallop: Tackling porn, feminism and big dreams |url=http://blog.ted.com/2009/12/02/qa_with_cindy_g/ |publisher=TED |date=2 December 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> She joined the London office of British advertising firm [[Bartle Bogle Hegarty]] in 1989 and was responsible for large accounts like [[Coca-Cola]], [[Ray-Ban]], and [[Polaroid Corporation|Polaroid]].<ref name="tedblog" /> In 1996, she helped start the Asia Pacific branch of BBH.<ref name="tedblog" /> She founded the US branch of BBH in 1998 and served as chair of the board. In 2003, Gallop won the Advertising Woman of the Year award from Advertising Women of New York.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web |title=Webdenda |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/19/business/012004webadden.html |work=The New York Times |date=19 January 2004 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> She founded her own brand and business innovation consultancy, Cindy Gallop LLC, in 2006.<ref name="nextwomen">{{cite web |title=Cindy Gallop |url=http://thenextwomen.com/next-women-list/item/cindy-gallop |publisher=The Next Women |year=2012 |accessdate=26 April |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630055233/http://www.thenextwomen.com/next-women-list/item/cindy-gallop |archivedate=30 June 2015 |df= }}</ref> She is known for her tagline: "I like to blow shit up. I am the [[Michael Bay]] of business."<ref name="nytech">{{cite web |url=http://wearenytech.com/19-cindy-gallop-founder-ceo-www-ifwerantheworld-com |title=Cindy Gallop |publisher=We Are NY Tech |date=3 December 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref>
At the 2009 [[TED (conference)|TED]] conference, Gallop launched the MakeLoveNotPorn web site in a 4-minute TEDTalk that the TED blog described as "one of the event's most talked about."<ref name="tedtalks" /> The goal of MakeLoveNotPorn is to provide a platform for people to post amateur porn videos.<ref name="tedtalks" /> She later published a TED book, ''Make Love Not Porn: Technology's Hardcore Impact on Human Behavior''.<ref name="tedbook">{{cite book |last=Gallop |first=Cindy |title=Make Love Not Porn: Technology's Hardcore Impact on Human Behavior |publisher=TED Books |date=22 February 2011 |asin=B004P1IX9U}}</ref> MakeLoveNotPorn.tv launched in August 2012, a video sharing site designed "to make #realworldsex socially acceptable and socially shareable."<ref name="mlnplaunch">{{cite web |url=http://blog.ted.com/2012/08/14/launched-today-in-beta-makelovenotporn-tv/ |title=Launched today in beta: MakeLoveNotPorn.tv |publisher=TED Blog |accessdate=12 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="Make Love Not Porn Founder Cindy Gallop’s Mission to Disrupt the Porn Industry">{{cite web |url=http://www.glammonitor.com/2015/05/16/make-love-not-porn-founder-cindy-gallops-mission-to-disrupt-the-porn-industry-2/ |title=Make Love Not Porn Founder Cindy Gallop's Mission to Disrupt the Porn Industry |publisher=Glammonitor |accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
In January 2010, Gallop launched IfWeRanTheWorld, a web platform designed to turn good intentions into action, by allowing people, brands, and companies to easily perform, trade, and co-ordinate "microactions."<ref name="nextwomen" /> One client of IfWeRanTheWorld is [[Levi's]], who worked with IfWeRanTheWorld to create a campaign to revitalise the manufacturing town of [[Braddock, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="usa">{{cite web |url=http://www.characterblog.com/2010/10/if-levis-ran-the-world-theyd-revitalize-an-all-american-town.php |title=If Levi's ran the world, they'd revitalize an all American Town |last=Chou |first=Jerri |publisher=USA network |date=28 October 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="harvard">{{cite book |title=If We Ran the World |first=Hanna |last=Halaburda |first2=Radka |last2=Dohnalova |first3=Aldo |last3=Sesia |publisher=Harvard Business School |ssrn=2020496 |date=16 March 2011}}</ref> Gallop is a professional public speaker in the areas of advertising, branding, and business strategy and has spoken at TED,<ref name="tedtalks" /> [[South by Southwest|SXSW]],<ref name="sxsw">{{cite web |url=http://austin2011.sched.org/speaker/cindygallop |title=Cindy Gallop: The End of Shame: or, Getting Over Oversharing |publisher=Sched* SXSW 2011 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> the [[Association of National Advertisers]] conference,<ref name="ana">{{cite web |url=http://www.ana.net/miccontent/showvideo/id/anc2010-ifwerantheworld |title=The Future of Advertising: Reinvention for Growth |publisher=Association of National Advertisers |accessdate=27 April 2012 |date=15 October 2010}}</ref> [[Web 2.0 Summit|Web 2.0]],<ref name="web20">{{cite web |url=http://www.web2expo.com/webexny2011/public/schedule/speaker/122836 |title=Speaker: Cindy Gallop |publisher=Web 2.0 Expo New York 2011 |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> [[ad:tech]],<ref name="adtech">{{cite web |url=http://www.adotas.com/2005/12/around-the-world-with-bbhs-cindy-gallop-keynote-speaker-adtech-ny-2005/ |title=Around the World with BBH's Cindy Gallop, Keynote Speaker, Ad:Tech NY 2005 |last=Gottlieb |first=Jaime |date=6 December 2005 |publisher=Adotas |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> and other conferences.
==The black apartment==
Gallop's unique black-themed New York apartment was a set for [[The Notorious B.I.G.]]'s music video "[[Nasty Girl (The Notorious B.I.G. song)|Nasty Girl]]."<ref name="apartmenttherapy">{{cite web|url=http://www.apartmenttherapy.com/look-the-black-apartment-64212 |title=Look! Cindy Gallop's Black Apartment |last=Govindan |first=Range |publisher=Apartment Therapy.com |date=25 September 2008 |accessdate=26 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130117035713/http://www.apartmenttherapy.com/look-the-black-apartment-64212 |archivedate=17 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Her apartment has been profiled by ''[[Dwell (magazine)|Dwell]]'',<ref name="dwell">{{cite web |url=http://www.dwell.com/videos/Bold-Color-Small-Space-The-Black-Apartment.html |title=Bold Color, Small Space: The Black Apartment |last=Nadeau |first=Gary |publisher=Dwell |date=7 August 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413092334/http://www.dwell.com/videos/Bold-Color-Small-Space-The-Black-Apartment.html |archivedate=13 April 2012 |df= }}</ref> Apartment Therapy.com,<ref name="apartmenttherapy" />{{Dead link|date=October 2016}} ''[[The Atlantic]]'',<ref name="atlantic">{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/video/index/250034/ |title=Cindy Gallop's Black Apartment |last=Stone |first=Paul |work=The Atlantic |date=16 December 2011 |accessdate=26 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209143551/http://www.theatlantic.com/video/index/250034 |archivedate=9 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> The Selby<ref name="theselby">{{cite web |url=http://www.theselby.com/3_19_10_CindyGallop/index.html |last=Selby |first=Todd |title=Cindy Gallop |publisher=The Selby |date=5 April 2010 |accessdate=27 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603121456/http://www.theselby.com/3_19_10_CindyGallop/index.html |archivedate=3 June 2012 |df= }}</ref> and ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine,<ref name="newyork">{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/homedesign/fall2006/21947/ |title=Where the Boys Were |last=Schoeneman |first=Deborah |work=New York |date=1 October 2006 |accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> among many others.

{{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Doug Barrowman | image = Doug Barrowman.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Douglas Alan Barrowman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1965|3|1}} | birth_place = [[Glasgow]] | nationality = Scottish | citizenship = United Kingdom |education = Bachelor of Accountancy | other_names = | occupation = Businessperson and investor | partner = [[Michelle Mone]] | alma_mater = [[Glasgow University]] | notable_works = | known_for = Founding Aston Ventures and The Knox Group of Companies }} '''Douglas Alan Barrowman''' is a Scottish businessman and investor. He is the founder and Chairman of the Knox Group of Companies.<ref>{{cite news|title=We could do with 120,000 people|url=http://www.iomtoday.co.im/news/business/we-could-do-with-120-000-people-1-8043707 |accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=[[Isle of Man Newspapers|Isle of Man Today]]}}</ref><ref name="independent">{{cite news|title=View from the top|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/property/house-and-home/view-from-the-top-5354452.html|accessdate=7 February 2017|work=[[The Independent]]|date=10 March 2004}}</ref> Barrowman also founded Aston Ventures Group and previously worked at 3i.
==Early life== Douglas "Doug" Barrowman was born on 1 March 1965 in [[Glasgow]], Scotland. He was raised in [[Simshill]], before moving to [[Rutherglen]] at the age of 13, where Barrowman attended [[Kings Park Secondary School]]. He later attended [[Glasgow University]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Accountancy]] degree in 1985.<ref>{{cite news|title=A tale of two towers|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/business/property/a-tale-of-two-towers-1048674|accessdate=7 February 2017|work=[[Manchester Evening News]]|date=15 February 2007}}</ref> Barrowman was the first person from his family to attend university.<ref name=ST>{{cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/uk/scottish-daily-mail/20161210/282175060747620|title=PressReader.com – Connecting People Through News|work=Scottish Daily Mail}}</ref>
==Career== After graduating, Barrowman completed his professional examinations and qualified as a [[Chartered Accountant]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/2322774/brit-bra-queen-lady-michelle-mone-has-the-hots-for-superyacht-owning-billionaire-tycoon-doug-barrowman/|title=Bra queen Michelle Mone finds love with billionaire tycoon who owns TWO superyachts|date=3 December 2016|work=The Sun}}</ref> At the age of twenty he set up paintball sites in Scotland as his first business. He then spent three years at [[private equity fund]] [[3i]].<ref name="mailonline">{{cite news|title=Bra queen Michelle Mone finds love again|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3998072/Bra-queen-Michelle-Mone-finds-love-billionaire-tycoon-superyacht-fleet-FIVE-Ferraris.html|accessdate=7 February 2017|work=[[Daily Mail]]}}</ref> Barrowman resigned from 3i in 1992, to pursue his own business interest in corporate finance,<ref name="mailonline" /><ref name="en">{{cite news|title=A tale of two Dougies|url=http://www.enforbusiness.com/feature/tale-two-dougies|accessdate=7 February 2017|publisher=Enforbusiness}}</ref> and set up his own corporate finance practice during the 1990s at the age of thirty.<ref name="en" /> He exited from this practice in 1999, to concentrate on his own private investment vehicle Aston Ventures, which he founded in the late 1990s.<ref name="en" />
Over the next ten years, Aston Ventures made 13 acquisitions of "old economy" businesses, including the third largest cable making company in the world B3 Cables, with a total turnover of about £400 million over that period. In 2008 Barrowman moved to the Isle of Man and founded The Knox Group of Companies which owned several businesses as well as Barrowman's interest in Aston Ventures. The Group is engaged in Private Equity, Property and Wealth Management.<ref name="independent" /><ref name="en" /><ref name=IM>{{cite web|url=https://www.insidermedia.com/insider/northwest/53935-barrowman-builds-new-venture|title=Barrowman builds new venture|first=Insider Media|last=Ltd}}</ref> In 2011 Barrowman co-founded the KHG Private Equity Fund.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebusinessdesk.com/northwest/news/138834-aston-ventures-new-vehicle-ready-to-invest|title=Aston Ventures' new vehicle ready to invest |date=10 March 2011|publisher=The Business Desk}}</ref> The Knox Group of Companies has funds under management and administration of £1.5 billion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Knox Group of companies|url=http://knoxgroupplc.com/|website=''Knoxgroupplc.com''|accessdate=7 February 2017}}</ref> In 2017 Barrowman became the interim Chairman of Ve Interactive, after an emergency cash injection and investment into the firm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2017/03/11/tech-unicorn-ve-interactives-valuation-slashed-300m/|title=Tech unicorn Ve Interactive's valuation slashed to £300m|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>
==Personal life== Barroman has six homes, an automobile collection with fifteen cars, and a private jet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/15125685.Michelle_Mone_treats_billionaire_boyfriend_to_unique_birthday_surprise/|title=Michelle Mone reveals amazing birthday treat she has in store for new boyfriend|work=The Evening Times}}</ref> He was featured on a 2015 episode of the television series ''Million Pound Mega Yacht'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.scot/culture/14857726.The_weekend_s_TV_highlights/|title=The weekend's TV highlights|work=The National}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://able.co.nz/news/entry/highlights-mega-yachts|title=Highlights: Mega-Yachts |publisher=ABLE}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noted.co.nz/culture/television/on-tv-march-26-2016/|title=On TV: March 26, 2016 – The Listener|last=Noted|publisher=Noted}}</ref> featuring his 183-foot yacht named ''Turquoise''. He is also an art collector, with pieces by [[Picasso]], [[Salvador Dali]], and [[Marc Chagall]]. Barrowman has four children, two from each of his prior marriages.<ref name=ST /> Barrowman is also the founder of The Barrowman Foundation, a charitable organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://barrowmanfoundation.com/doug-barrowman/|title=About Doug Barrowman}}</ref> He has also lent pieces from his art collection to institutions such as the Manx Museum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isleofman.com/News/details/73028/knox-inspired-dress-now-on-display-at-manx-museum|title=Knox-inspired dress now on display at Manx Museum - Isle of Man News :: isleofman.com|last=isleofman.com}}</ref> Barrowman has also lent pieces to London Galleries, such as his [[George Daniels (watchmaker)|George Daniels]] Space Traveller Watch, which was featured at the V&A for the exhibition ''What is Luxury''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/design/54389/the-va-explores-the-meaning-of-luxury.html|title=The V&A explores the meaning of Luxury-Telegraph}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=April 2015}} '''Emma Forster''' (born 1976) is a South Australian television presenter, director of tourist attraction Swim with the Tuna and advisor for the company, [[Oceanic Victor]]. She lives in [[Port Lincoln]] where she has developed several properties. She has worked as a presenter on the seafood, fishing and boating television program ''[[Out of the Blue (2002 TV series)|Out of the Blue]],'' is a friend and business advisor to multi-millionaire [[Southern bluefin tuna|tuna]] rancher [[Tony Santic]] and is a former girlfriend of retired South Australian treasurer, [[Kevin Foley (South Australian politician)|Kevin Foley]].{{Cite news|url = http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/new-granite-island-tourism-proposal-to-allow-swimming-and-hand-feeding-of-fish/story-fni6uo1m-1227316574201|title = New Granite Island tourism proposal to allow swimming and hand feeding of fish|date = 23 April 2015|newspaper = The Advertiser}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/its-over-for-emma-kevin-foley/story-e6frea83-1111113432015|title = It's over for Emma, Kevin Foley|last = Meegan|first = Genevieve|date = 28 April 2007|access-date = 24 April 2015|newspaper = The Advertiser}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/tv-host-cops-drink-drive-fine-after-long-lunch/story-e6frg996-1111112747968|title = TV host cops drink-drive fine after long lunch|last = Edwards|first = Verity|date = 28 December 2006|access-date = 24 April 2015|newspaper = The Australian}} In 2013, Forster was co-managing her family's business, Calypso Star Charters and her partner was [[abalone]] diver David "Bucky" Buckland.{{Cite news|url = http://www.theaustralian.com.au/life/weekend-australian-magazine/deadly-descent-for-port-lincolns-abalone-divers/story-e6frg8h6-1226781593038|title = Deadly descent for Port Lincoln's abalone divers|last = Dalton|first = Trent|date = 14 December 2013|access-date = 27 November 2015|newspaper = The Australian}} In 2014, Forster served as Secretary for the Port Lincoln Chamber of Commerce and Tourism.{{Cite web|url = http://portlincolnchamber.com.au/about/|title = About the Port Lincoln Chamber of Commerce|accessdate = 14 January 2014|website = Port Lincoln Chamber of Commerce|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140114111927/http://portlincolnchamber.com.au/about/|archivedate=14 January 2014}} Forster is a fisher, and holds longstanding national and South Australian women's and junior records for an [[eagle ray]] she caught in [[Spencer Gulf]] in 1987 on 10 kg line. The fish weighed 68.5 kilograms and was caught off [[Thistle Island]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.gfaa.asn.au/new/index.php/record-applications/records/capture-records|title = Capture records|accessdate = 24 April 2015|website = Game Fishing Association Australia}} == Career == === Swim with the Tuna === Forster is a director of Port Lincoln-based tourism venture, ''Swim with the Tuna. ''Operations were first trialled in South Australia's [[Port Lincoln, South Australia|Boston Bay]] in 2010{{Cite web|url=http://www.atuna.com/NewsArchive/ViewArticle.asp?ID=9115 |title=Trail Run 'Swim with the Tuna' A Success |date=10 December 2010 |accessdate=24 April 2015 |website=atuna |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191841/http://www.atuna.com/NewsArchive/ViewArticle.asp?ID=9115 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }} before commencing commercial operations in 2011. The business intended to move to [[Kangaroo Island]], but has faced opposition from conservationists{{Cite web|url=http://www.atuna.com/NewsArchive/ViewArticle.asp?ID=9875 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20150424101401/http://www.atuna.com/NewsArchive/ViewArticle.asp?ID=9875 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-04-24 |title=Conservationists Find 'Swim With Tuna' Inappropriate |date=28 July 2011 |accessdate=24 April 2015 |website=atuna }} and residents. Proposals to relocated the facility comprising a modified tuna pen and floating pontoon to [[Nepean Bay]] have been rejected on two occasions, most recently in 2012.{{Cite news|url = http://www.news.com.au/travel/travel-updates/kangaroo-island-residents-reject-plan-to-relocate-a-tuna-pen-and-pontoon-from-port-lincoln/story-e6frfq80-1226478406645|title = Kangaroo Island residents reject plan to relocate a tuna pen and pontoon from Port Lincoln|date = 20 September 2012|access-date = 24 April 2015}} Oceanic Victor (another business for which Forster works as an advisor) proposes to offer a very similar experience to that offered by ''Swim with the Tuna'', located off Granite Island in [[Encounter Bay]]. The Swim with the Tuna business was sold in 2015 ahead of the possible relocation to Victor Harbor. Forster claimed that they had held some of their fish captive for five years, the largest having reached a weight of 85 kilograms.{{Cite web|title = Last lap for Swim with the Tuna|url = http://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/3393380/last-lap-for-swim-with-the-tuna/|website = Port Lincoln Times|accessdate = 21 October 2015}} === Granite Island observatory === Emma's father Ron Forster built a floating underwater observatory in 1989. Her father's construction was first used in Port Lincoln, where it assisted the development of the tuna industry. It was later sold to Stephen Edwards, who moored it off [[Granite Island (South Australia)|Granite Island]]. It operated there as a tourist attraction and educational facility from 1997 to 2004. In 2015, Forster was revealed to be working as an advisor for [[Oceanic Victor]], a company which intends to re-establish a similar facility off Granite Island. The venture intends to offer people the opportunity to swim with [[Southern bluefin tuna]] and other marine species, feed fish and observe them underwater.{{Cite news|url = http://www.victorharbortimes.com.au/story/3031974/underwater-observatory-among-eco-tourism-plans-for-granite-island/|title = Port Lincoln developers reveal eco-tourism plans for Granite Island|last = Simmons|first = Michael|date = 23 April 2015|access-date = 24 April 2015|newspaper = Victor Harbor Times}} The two directors of Oceanic Victor are also the CEO and Operations Manager of Tony's Tuna International, [[Tony Šantić]] and Michael "Mick" Dyer. Tony Šantić is a long-term friend of Forster's who provided her with a character reference after she was charged after crashing her Mercedes and recording a blood-alcohol level of 0.224% in August 2006.{{Cite news|url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2006-12-27/foleys-girlfriend-fined-for-drink-driving/2161780|title = Foley's girlfriend fined for drink-driving|date = 27 December 2006|access-date = 25 April 2015|publisher = ABC}} She returned to the road in March 2007 with a provisional driver's license.{{Cite news|url = http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/foleys-girl-back-behind-wheel/story-e6frea83-1111113170452|title = Foley's girl back behind wheel|last = Wheatley|first = Kim|date = 16 March 2007|access-date = 25 April 2015|first2 = Ivon|last2 = Perrin|newspaper = The Advertiser}} === Great white sharks === Forster has co-managed her father's business, Calypso Star Charters, which offers shark cage diving experiences to tourists. Forster's partner David "Bucky" Buckland has encountered many great white sharks while diving for abalone. In 2013 Forster said of [[Great white shark]]s:
"The sharks are like rabbits now. They can breed and no one can catch them."
== Early life == Forster grew up on [[Fleurieu Peninsula]], where she attended [[Rapid Bay, South Australia|Rapid Bay Primary School]] and [[Yankalilla, South Australia|Yankalilla Area School]]. She undertook a Rotary Youth Exchange to Japan in 1993, at the age of 17.{{Cite news|url = http://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/2901690/locals-invited-to-hear-rotary-guest-speakers/|title = Locals invited to hear Rotary guest speakers|last = Harrison|first = Billie|date = 24 February 2015|access-date = 25 April 2015|newspaper = Port Lincoln Times}} == Ron Forster (father) == Emma Forster's father Ron Forster is fisherman,{{Cite web|title = Australian Fishing: Big numbers at Port Lincoln Tuna Classic – Fishing World|url = http://www.fishingworld.com.au/news/big-numbers-at-port-lincoln-tuna-classic|website = ''fishingworld.com.au''|accessdate = 26 November 2015}} land developer and charter business owner.{{Cite web|url = http://exploreeyrepeninsula.com.au/blog/2014/11/eyre-peninsula-success-at-south-australian-tourism-awards|title = EYRE PENINSULA SUCCESS AT SOUTH AUSTRALIAN TOURISM AWARDS|date = 18 November 2014|accessdate = 27 November 2015|website = Eyre Peninsula – Australia's seafood frontier}} With Rolf Czabayski, Forster founded the Port Lincoln Tuna Classic fishing competition, originally known as "The Shootout" in 2005. In 2006 he purchased Calypso Star Charters. The company offers tourists shark cage diving with [[Great white shark]]s and swimming with [[Australian sea lion|Australian sea-lion]]s out of Port Lincoln.{{Cite web|title=About Us – Shark Cage Diving |url=http://www.sharkcagediving.com.au/about-us/ |website=Shark Cage Diving |accessdate=26 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151127025928/http://www.sharkcagediving.com.au/about-us/ |archivedate=27 November 2015 |df= }} In 2007, Forster set a Game Fishing Association of Australia record for the largest [[samson fish]] caught by a male fisherman. The fish weighed 25 kilograms and as of 2015 the record remains unbroken.{{Cite web|title = Capture Records|url = http://www.gfaa.asn.au/records/records_list/capture_records_list.php?q=(firstname~contains~ron)(surname~contains~forster)|website = gfaa.asn.au|accessdate = 26 November 2015}} He is a member of the Game Fishing Club of South Australia and owns a boat called ''Long Shot''.{{Cite web|url = http://www.gamefishsa.org.au/pages/Books/ThePointer/sm%202013-14%20No%204%20Pointer.pdf|title = The Pointer|date = 1 September 2014|accessdate = 27 November 2015|website = |publisher = Game Fishing Club of South Australia}} Circa 2007, Forster began planning a major residential and holiday land development project called Sleaford Cove.{{Cite web|title = $750 million|url = http://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/1182305/750-million/|website = Port Lincoln Times|accessdate = 26 November 2015}} The proposal covers 200 hectares overlooking [[Sleaford Bay]] and comprises approximately 350 housing allotments and 50 holiday units. In 2013 community concerns were raised regarding the Sleaford Cove project's potential environmental impacts.{{Cite web|title = Sleaford residents raise development concerns|url = http://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/1239132/sleaford-residents-raise-development-concerns/|website = Port Lincoln Times|accessdate = 26 November 2015}} In 2014 Ron Forster was awarded at the South Australian tourism awards for "outstanding achievement by an individual".{{Cite web|title = Local tourism winners|url = http://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/2702177/local-tourism-winners/|website = Port Lincoln Times|accessdate = 26 November 2015}} As of 2015, Ron Forster is involved in the sale of land at Point Boston.{{Cite web|title = Positive signs for Pt Boston|url = http://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/3302190/positive-signs-for-pt-boston/|website = Port Lincoln Times|accessdate = 26 November 2015}} Forster was involved in the development of the Lincoln Cove marina in the 1990s.{{Cite web|title = Sleaford plan on again|url = http://www.portlincolntimes.com.au/story/418780/sleaford-plan-on-again/|website = Port Lincoln Times|accessdate = 26 November 2015}} Forster's land development company Sea Marine Holdings Pty. Ltd. was established in 1992. His wife Janet Forster is a fellow director and company secretary.{{Cite web|title = Sea Marine Holdings Pty. Ltd. in Port Lincoln SA|url = http://listings.ftb-companies-au.com/l/102533410/Sea-Marine-Holdings-Pty-Ltd-in-Port-Lincoln-SA|website = listings.ftb-companies-au.com|accessdate = 27 November 2015}} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Forster, Emma}} [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Port Lincoln, South Australia]] [[Category:Australian television people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1976 births]]
