Veronika |residence = |occupation = |religion = [[Russian Orthodox]] |signature = |website = [http://www.duma.gov.ru/structure/deputies/131138/ Sergey Naryshkin] |footnotes = }} '''Sergey Yevgenyevich Naryshkin''' ({{lang-rus|Серге́й Евге́ньевич Нары́шкин|p=sʲɪrˈɡʲej jɪˈvɡʲenʲɪvʲɪtɕ nɐˈrɨʂkʲɪn}}; born 27 October 1954) is a [[Russia]]n official, politician and businessman who has been [[Chairman of the State Duma]] (2011 - 2016). Previously he was head of the [[Russian presidential administration|Administration]] of the [[President of Russia]] from May 2008 to December 2011; he was also chairman of the [[Historical Truth Commission]] in May 2009 until it was dissolved in February 2012. ==Early life and education== Sergei Ivanovich Naryshkin was born in Leningrad and graduated from [[Baltic State Technical University|Leningrad Institute of Mechanics]] with a degree in engineering in 1978. In the 1990s he also graduated from [[International Management Institute of Saint Petersburg]] with a degree in economics.{{cite web |title=Sergei Naryshkin|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/mt_profile/sergei_naryshkin/434258.html |publisher=''[[The Moscow Times]]'' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111029162554/http://www.themoscowtimes.com/mt_profile/sergei_naryshkin/434258.html |archive-date=October 29, 2011 |quote=Education: Radio-mechanical engineering, Leningrad Mechanical Institute, 1978. Economics, Petersburg International Management Institute, 1997.}} In 2015, Naryshkin's dissertation in economics was exposed as fraudulent in an investigation by [[Dissernet]], with more than half of the text plagiarized from other publications.{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/cover_story/2016/05/the_thriving_russian_black_market_in_dissertations_and_the_crusaders_fighting.html|title=The Craziest Black Market in Russia|last=Neyfakh|first=Leon|date=May 22, 2016 |publisher=''Slate''|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339|access-date=December 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230022705/http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/cover_story/2016/05/the_thriving_russian_black_market_in_dissertations_and_the_crusaders_fighting.html |archive-date=December 30, 2016 |quote=Late last year, Russian newspapers reported what would have qualified as a stunning piece of news almost anywhere else: The chairman of the country’s largest parliamentary body had been exposed as a plagiarist. Sergei Naryshkin, the former chief of staff in Vladimir Putin’s administration and a prominent member of his United Russia party, stood accused of receiving the Russian equivalent of a doctoral degree on the strength of a dissertation in which more than half of the pages contained material lifted from other sources.}} ==Career== In 1982 he was appointed Deputy Vice-Rector of [[Leningrad Polytechnical Institute]]. In the 1980s he served in the Soviet Embassy in [[Brussels]]. Some sources suggested that while there he worked for [[KGB]] after he had been a fellow student of [[Vladimir Putin]] at a group of KGB Higher School.{{cite web|title=Gazeta page|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/2007/02/15/oa_231787.shtml|publisher=Gazeta|accessdate=31 May 2012}} From 1992 until 1995 he worked in the Committee for Economy and Finance of [[Saint Petersburg City Administration|Saint Petersburg Mayor Office]]. After he left, he became the chief of the external investment department of Promstroybank—a position he would hold until 1997. From 1997 until 1998, Naryshkin led the Investment Department of the [[Leningrad Oblast]] government. From 1998 until 2004, he was the Chairman of the Committee for External Economic and International Relations of the government of Leningrad Oblast. In early 2004 he was a deputy head of the economic department of the [[Russian presidential administration]]. From March through September 2004, Naryshkin was a deputy chief of staff of the [[Russian government]]. Since 2004 he has been a member of the board of directors of [[Sovkomflot]] and a deputy chairman of the board of directors of [[Rosneft]]. Since August 31, 2004, Naryshkin has also been Chairman of the Board of Directors of [[Channel One (Russia)|Channel One]] of the Russian television. Since September 13, 2004, he has been a Minister, Chief of Staff of the Government of Russia. On February 15, 2007, President [[Vladimir Putin]] announced that Naryshkin had been appointed Deputy Prime Minister of Russia for external economic activity, focusing on collaboration with the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]]. In May 2008, Naryshkin was appointed chief of the [[Presidential Administration of Russia]]. In May 2009, President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] appointed him chairman of the [[Historical Truth Commission]]. Since the rise of tensions between European Union and Russia in 2014 Naryshkin was perceived as one of the main coordinators of contacts with European far-right and far-left parties supporting Russian foreign policy in Europe.{{Cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/europe-s-east/news/alde-wants-investigation-of-le-pen-s-contacts-with-moscow/|title=ALDE wants investigation of Le Pen’s contacts with Moscow|website=EurActiv.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-09-23}} {{See also|Russia-European Union relations}} In September 2016 Naryshkin was appointed as chief of Russia's [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)|Foreign Intelligence Service]] (SVR).{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-37442330|title=Putin names ally Sergei Naryshkin as new foreign spy chief|date=2016-09-22|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-09-23}} ==Chairman of the State Duma== Naryshkin [[Russian legislative election, 2011|was elected]] to the [[State Duma]], the [[lower house]] of the [[Federal Assembly of Russia|Russian parliament]] in December 2011. When the Duma began meeting for its new term on 21 December 2011, Naryshkin was elected as [[Chairman of the State Duma]]; he received 238 votes in favor of his candidacy, while 88 deputies opposed him.[http://en.ria.ru/russia/20111221/170407409.html "Naryshkin named Russia’s parliamentary speaker"], RIA Novosti, 21 December 2011. Retrieved 21 December 2011. On June 2012 Naryshkin signed a resolution on setting up a culture council under the State Duma speaker. The council is “a standing advisory body”. The tasks of the council are “the examination and drafting of initiatives on topical problems of legislative regulations in culture and associated industries, the development of recommendations on culture for the use in lawmaking”.{{cite news|url=http://www.russkiymir.ru/russkiymir/en/news/common/news7020.html|title=State Duma Speaker Sergei Naryshkin Forms Culture Council|publisher=[[Russkiy Mir]]|accessdate=6 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130417182806/http://www.russkiymir.ru/russkiymir/en/news/common/news7020.html|archivedate=17 April 2013|df=}} On September 2, 2013, Naryshkin stated that there are no political prisoners in today's Russia.[http://grani.ru/Politics/Russia/Parliament/Duma/m.218446.html Grani.ru], ''Нарышкин: В России нет политзаключенных [Naryshkin: Russia has no political prisoners]'', 2 September 2013. == Membership in advisory and scientific councils and commissions == Sergey Naryshkin – Chairman of the Board of Trustees [[Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration|The Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration (RANEPA)]] [http://www.ranepa.ru/eng/about-academy-ranepa/board-of-trustees Board of Trustees RANEPA] ==Sanctions== As a result of the [[2014 Crimean crisis]], the federal government of the United States under Barack Obama blacklisted{{efn|He was placed on the [[Office of Foreign Assets Control#Specially Designated Nationals List|Specially Designated Nationals List (SDN)]], a [[List of individuals sanctioned during the Ukrainian crisis|list of individuals sanctioned]] as “members of the Russian leadership’s inner circle.”}} Naryshkin and other close friends of the [[Russian president]], including [[Sergei Ivanov]] and [[Gennadi Timchenko]].{{Cite web|title=Executive Order - Blocking Property of Additional Persons Contributing to the Situation in Ukraine |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/03/20/executive-order-blocking-property-additional-persons-contributing-situat |publisher=The White House - Office of the Press Secretary}}{{Cite web|title=Treasury Sanctions Russian Officials, Members Of The Russian Leadership’s Inner Circle, And An Entity For Involvement In The Situation In Ukraine |url=http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/jl23331.aspx |publisher=US Department of the treasury}}[http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/OFAC-Enforcement/Pages/20140320_33.aspx www.treasury.gov][http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/SDN-List/Pages/default.aspx Specially Designated Nationals List (SDN)]{{cite web|last=Shuklin |first=Peter |title=Putin's inner circle: who got in a new list of US sanctions |url=https://news.liga.net/articles/politics/1066761-blizhniy_krug_putina_kto_popal_v_novyy_spisok_sanktsiy_ssha.htm |publisher=liga.net |date=March 21, 2014 |accessdate=February 20, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207152258/http://news.liga.net/articles/politics/1066761-blizhniy_krug_putina_kto_popal_v_novyy_spisok_sanktsiy_ssha.htm |archivedate=February 7, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web | last = President of The United States | title = Ukraine EO13661 | url = https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/ukraine_eo2.pdf | publisher = Federal Register | date = March 19, 2016 | accessdate = February 20, 2016}} Nevertheless, he officially visited the U.S., along with other Russian top security chiefs, at the end of January 2018.[http://tass.com/world/988213 US suspends sanctions against Russian security chiefs during their visit to Washington] [[TASS]], 2 February 2018. ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{short description|messaging application}} {{Hatnote|This article is about the software. For company that produces this software, see [[Slack Technologies]]. Not to be confused with [[Slackware]].}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox software | name = Slack (software) | title = Slack | logo = Slack Technologies Logo.svg | screenshot = | caption = | collapsible = | author = [[Stewart Butterfield]], Eric Costello, [[Cal Henderson]], and Serguei Mourachov<ref name="SlackOpen" /> | developer = [[Slack Technologies]] | released = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2013|08}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Flickr Cofounders Launch Slack, An Email Killer |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3015730/flickr-cofounders-launch-slack-an-email-killer |last=Zax |first=David |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> | ver layout = stacked | discontinued = | programming language = [[Electron (software framework)|Electron]] ([[C++]], [[JavaScript]], [[ECMAScript]], etc.)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://slack.com/jobs/69902/desktop-application-engineer |title=Desktop Application Engineer |website=slack.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913032127/https://slack.com/jobs/69902/desktop-application-engineer |archive-date=September 13, 2018 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> | operating system = [[Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Linux]], [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack apps for computers, phones & tablets |url=https://get.slack.help/hc/en-us/articles/201746897-Slack-apps-for-computers-phones-tablets |author=Slack |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> [[Commodore 64]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack client for Commodore 64 |url=http://1amstudios.com/2016/11/27/c64-slack-client/ |date=November 27, 2016 |first=Jeffrey |last=Harris |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> | platform = | size = | genre = [[Collaborative software]]<ref name="SlackInfoCrunchBase">{{cite web |url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/tiny-speck |title=Crunchbase - Slack Technologies |work=[[CrunchBase]] |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> | website = {{URL|https://slack.com}} | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] }}
'''Slack''' is a [[Cloud computing|cloud]]-based set of proprietary team [[Collaborative software|collaboration tools]] and [[online service|services]], founded by [[Stewart Butterfield]].<ref name="SlackOpen">{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/02/05/slacks-co-founders-take-home-the-crunchie-for-founder-of-the-year/ |title=Slack's Co-Founders Take Home The Crunchie For Founder Of The Year |last=Kumparak |first=Greg |date=February 5, 2015 |website=TechCrunch.com |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> Slack began as an internal tool used by his company, [[Tiny Speck]], in the development of ''[[Glitch (video game)|Glitch]]'', a now defunct online game.<ref name="Tam">{{cite web |title=Flickr founder plans to kill company e-mails with Slack |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/flickr-founder-plans-to-kill-company-e-mails-with-slack/ |last=Tam |first=Donna |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Thomas">{{cite web |title=Die, Email, Die! A Flickr Cofounder Aims To Cut Us All Some Slack |url=https://readwrite.com/2013/08/14/stewart-butterfield-tiny-speck-slack/#awesm=~oogoYQh5KTzJkK |date=August 14, 2013 |last=Thomas |first=Owen |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> The name is an acronym for "Searchable Log of All Conversation and Knowledge".<ref name="Acronym">{{cite news |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/where-did-slack-get-its-name-2016-9 |title=Slack, the red hot $3.8 billion startup, has a hidden meaning behind its name |last=Kim |first=Eugene |date=September 27, 2016 |work=UK Business Insider |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
== History == Slack was launched in August 2013.<ref name=Koetsier /> In January 2015, Slack announced the acquisition of Screenhero.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.screenhero.com/post/109337923751/screenhero-joins-slack |title=Screenhero joins Slack |work=The Screenhero Blog |date=January 28, 2015 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
In March 2015, Slack announced that it had been hacked over the course of four days in February 2015, and that some number of users' data was compromised. That data included email addresses, usernames, hashed passwords, and, in some cases, phone numbers and Skype IDs that users had associated with their accounts. In response, Slack added [[two-factor authentication]] to their service.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Greenberg |first1=Andy |title=Slack Says It Was Hacked, Enables Two-Factor Authentication |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/slack-admits-hacked-enables-2-factor-authentication/ |website=Wired.com |publisher=Condé Nast |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=March 27, 2015}}</ref>
Slack used to offer compatibility with the non-proprietary [[Internet Relay Chat|IRC]] and [[XMPP]] messaging protocols, but announced in March 2018 that it would close the corresponding gateways by May 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/03/09/slack_cuts_ties_to_irc_and_xmpp/ |title=Slack cuts ties to IRC and XMPP, cos they don't speak Emoji |date=March 9, 2018 |last=Sharwood |first=Simon |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
In August 2018, Slack bought IP assets of [[Atlassian]]'s two enterprise communications tools, [[HipChat]] and Stride.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/07/26/slack-forms-key-alliance-as-atlassian-throws-in-the-towel-on-enterprise-collaboration/ |title=Slack forms key alliance as Atlassian throws in the towel on enterprise chat |work=TechCrunch |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=July 26, 2018 |last=Miller |first=Ron}}</ref>
== Features == While no longer using an [[IRC]] backend, Slack offers many IRC-like features, including persistent chat rooms (channels) organized by topic, private groups and direct messaging.<ref name=Thomas /> All content inside Slack is searchable, including files, conversations, and people. On the free plan, only the 10,000 most recent messages can be viewed and searched.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://get.slack.help/hc/en-us/articles/115002422943-Message-and-storage-limits-on-the-Free-plan |title=Message and storage limits on the Free plan |work=Slack Help Center |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> Users can add [[emoji]] buttons to their messages, which other users can then click on to express their reactions to messages.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack Adds Emoji Reactions |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/07/09/slack-adds-emoji-reactions/ |first=Jordan |last=Crook |date=July 9, 2015 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
=== Teams === Slack teams allow communities, groups, or teams to join through a specific URL or invitation sent by a team admin or owner. Although Slack was meant for organizational communication, it has been slowly turning into a community platform, a function for which users had previously used message boards or social media such as Facebook or LinkedIn groups.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blog.hootsuite.com/why-community-builders-are-choosing-slack/ |title=Why Slack is Exploding (as a Community-Building Platform) |publisher=hootsuite.com |date=July 8, 2015 |first=Matt |last=Diederichs |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> Many of these communities are categorized by topics which a group of people may be interested in discussing.
=== Messaging === Public channels allow team members to communicate without the use of email or group SMS (texting). They are open to everyone in the chat, provided they have first been invited to join the client. Private channels allow for private conversation between smaller sects of the overall group. These can be used to break up large teams into their own respective projects. Direct messages allow users to send private messages to a specific user rather than a group of people.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://slack.com/features |title=Features - Slack |last=Slack |website=Slack.com |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> Direct messages can include up to nine people (the originator plus eight people). Once started this direct message group can be converted to a private channel.
=== Integrations === Slack integrates with a large number of third-party services and supports community-built integrations.<ref>{{cite web |title=Why We Moved To Slack |url = https://blog.scrapinghub.com/2015/03/16/why-we-moved-to-slack |date=March 16, 2015 |access-date=October 13, 2018 |first=Pablo |last=Hoffman}}</ref> Major integrations include services such as [[Google Drive]], [[Trello]], [[Dropbox (service)|Dropbox]], [[Box (company)|Box]], [[Heroku]], IBM [[Bluemix]], [[Crashlytics]], [[GitHub]], [[Runscope]], [[Zendesk]],<ref name="Gannes">{{cite web |title=Flickr Co-Founder Stewart Butterfield Turns to Workplace Communication Tools With Slack |url=http://allthingsd.com/20130814/flickr-co-founder-stewart-butterfield-turns-to-workplace-communication-tools-with-slack/ |last=Gannes |first=Liz |date=August 14, 2013 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Augustine">{{cite web |title=A Review of the Slack Communication Service |url=https://www.lifewire.com/slack-sets-standard-team-communication-online-771603 |last=Augustine |first=Ann |date=May 19, 2018 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> and [[Zapier]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://zapier.com/apps/integrations |title=Zapier {{!}} The easiest way to automate your work |website=Zapier.com |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> In December 2015, Slack announced their app directory, consisting of over 150 integrations that users can install.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack launches an app store and an $80 million fund to invest in new integrations |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/12/15/10235114/slack-app-directory-80-million-fund |date=December 15, 2015 |first=Casey |last=Newton |website=TheVerge.com |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> In March 2018, Slack announced its partnership with the financial and human capital management firm [[Workday, Inc.|Workday]]; Adding to Slack's list of plugins. This integration allows Workday customers to access features from directly within the Slack interface.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.itbusiness.ca/news/workday-and-slack-announce-partnership-google-microsoft-and-facebook-on-the-horizon/100574 |title=Workday and Slack announce partnership; Google, Microsoft and Facebook on the horizon |work=IT Business |access-date=October 13, 2018 |first=Alex |last=Coop |date=March 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.hrtechnologist.com/news/workforce-scheduling/industry-leaders-slack-amp-workday-are-now-partners/ |title=Industry Leaders Slack & Workday are Now Partners |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=May 27, 2018 |last=News Desk |first=The HRT}}</ref>
== Platforms == Slack provides mobile apps for iOS, Android, and Windows Phone (beta),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.windowscentral.com/slack-windows-phone-app-beta-now-available-everyone |title=Slack for Windows Phone app beta appears to be available for everyone |work=Windows Central |date=August 19, 2015 |first=John |last=Callaham |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> in addition to their web browser client and electron desktop clients for macOS, Windows, and Linux (beta). Slack is also available for the [[Apple Watch]], allowing users to send direct messages, see mentions, and make simple replies.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack brings its app to the Apple Watch (video) |url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/04/20/slack-brings-its-app-to-the-apple-watch-video/ |work=VentureBeat |date=April 20, 2015 |first=Jordan |last=Novet |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> It was featured on the home screen of the Apple Watch in a 2015 promotional video.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/salesforce-evernote-slack-and-other-apple-watch-business-apps-2015-3?r=UK&IR=T |title=5 Apple Watch apps that will help you do your job |first=Julie |last=Bort |date=March 9, 2015 |work=Business Insider |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> Slack has been made to run on a [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]] via [[Satellaview]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/neggmk/you-can-now-receive-slack-messages-inside-a-super-nintendo-game |publisher=[[Vice Media]] |title=You Can Now Receive Slack Messages Inside a Super Nintendo Game |first=Ian |last=Birnbaum |date=October 22, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://bert.org/2018/10/18/slack-on-a-snes/ |first=Bertrand |last=Fan |date=October 18, 2018 |title=Slack on a SNES}}</ref>
== Business model == Slack is a [[freemium]] product, whose main paid features are the ability to search more than 10,000 archived messages and add unlimited apps and integrations. They claim support for an unlimited number of users. When [[freeCodeCamp]] attempted to switch its community of over 8,000 users to Slack in 2015, however, they experienced many technical issues and were advised by Slack support to limit their channels to "no more than 1,000 users (ideally more like 500)".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://medium.freecodecamp.org/so-yeah-we-tried-slack-and-we-deeply-regretted-it-391bcc714c81 |title=So Yeah We Tried Slack… and We Deeply Regretted It |publisher=FreeCodeCamp.com |date=June 21, 2015 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/slack-free-unlimited-plan-has-limits-2015-6 |title=Startup founder claims $2.8 billion startup Slack is misleading people about its free 'unlimited' plan |first=Eugene |last=Kim |publisher=BusinessInsider.com |date=June 22, 2015 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> That specific limit no longer applied by January 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://davechen.net/2017/01/slack-user-limit/ |title=Despite its marketing, Slack's free tier limits your total number of users |publisher=DaveChen.net |first=Dave |last=Chen |date=January 20, 2017 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
=== Funding === The company originally raised nearly $43 million in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack, Stewart Butterfield's Collaboration Software Startup, Has Raised $42.75M |url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/04/25/stewart-butterfields-collaboration-app-slack-raises-42-75m/ |publisher=[[TechCrunch]] |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=April 25, 2014}}</ref> In October 2014, the company raised $120 million in [[venture capital]] with a $1.2 billion [[valuation (finance)|valuation]] led by [[Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]] and [[Google Ventures]]. Earlier investors [[Andreessen Horowitz]], [[Accel Partners]] and [[The Social+Capital Partnership]] also participated in this round.<ref>{{cite news |title=Why Slack is worth $1bn: it's trying to change how we work |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/nov/03/why-slack-is-worth-1bn-work-chat-app |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=October 13, 2018 |first=Alex |last=Hern |date=November 3, 2014}}</ref>
In March 2015, Slack signed a deal with investors to raise up to $160 million in a funding round that valued the company at $2.76 billion. New investors included [[Institutional Venture Partners]], [[Horizons Ventures]], [[Index Ventures]] and DST Global.<ref>{{cite news |last=MacMillan |first=Douglas |title=Slack's Valuation More Than Doubles to $2.8 Billion in Five Months |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2015/03/26/slacks-valuation-more-than-doubles-to-2-8-billion-in-five-months/ |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=March 26, 2015 |publisher=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> In April 2015, the company raised another $160 million.<ref>{{cite web |title=Used Daily By 750K Workers, Slack Raises $160M, Valuing Collaboration Startup At $2.8B |url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/04/16/used-daily-by-750k-workers-slack-raises-160m-to-value-collaboration-startup-at-2-8b/ |publisher=[[Techcrunch]] |access-date=October 13, 2018 |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |date=April 15, 2015}}</ref> In April 2016, the company announced that it had raised an additional $200 million in funding.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/04/01/slack-raises-200m-at-3-8b-valuation-for-business-messaging/ |title=Slack is work chat's runaway train, raises $200M at $3.8B |first1=Katie |last1=Roof |first2=Josh |last2=Constine |date=April 1, 2016 |publisher=[[Techcrunch]] |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
On July 26, 2018, [[Atlassian]] announced the shutdown of its competing [[HipChat]] and [[Stride (software)|Stride]] effective February 11, 2019, and the sale of their intellectual property to Slack. Slack will pay an undisclosed amount over three years to assume the user bases of the services, and Atlassian will take a minority investment in Slack. The companies also announced a commitment to work on integration of Slack with Atlassian services.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/7/26/17619482/slack-hipchat-acquisition-stride-atlassian-partnership-microsoft-teams-competition |title=Slack buys HipChat with plans to shut it down and migrate users to its chat service |work=The Verge |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=July 26, 2018 |first=Stefan |last=Etienne}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/07/26/atlassians-hipchat-and-stride-to-be-discontinued-with-slack-buying-up-the-ip/ |title=Atlassian’s HipChat and Stride to be discontinued, with Slack buying up the IP |first=Greg |last=Kumparak |work=[[TechCrunch]] |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=July 26, 2018}}</ref>
== Reception == 8,000 customers signed up for the service within 24 hours of its launch in August 2013.<ref name=Koetsier>{{cite web |title=Flickr founder Stewart Butterfield's new Slack signed up 8,000 companies in 24 hours |url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/08/15/flickr-founder-stewart-butterfields-new-slack-signed-up-8000-companies-in-24-hours/ |last=Koetsier |first=John |work=VentureBeat |date=August 15, 2013 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Fingas>{{cite web |title=Flickr creator takes sign-ups for Slack, an office collaboration tool with universal search |url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/08/14/flickr-creator-takes-sign-ups-for-slack-collaboration-tool/ |last=Fingas |first=Jon |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=August 14, 2013}}</ref> In February 2015, the company wrote that around 10,000 new daily active users were signing up each week, and had more than 135,000 paying customers spread across 60,000 teams.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack growth skyrockets: 10,000 new active users each week |date=February 12, 2015 |last=Griffith |first=Erin |url=http://fortune.com/2015/02/12/slack-growth/ |access-date=October 13, 2018 |website=Fortune.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Billion-dollar startup Slack says it's adding $1 million in new contracts every 11 days |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/slack-growth-after-one-year-2015-2 |date=February 12, 2015 |last=Kim |first=Eugene |access-date=October 13, 2018 |website=BusinessInsider.com}}</ref> By April 2015, those numbers had grown to 200,000 paid subscribers and a total of 750,000 daily active users.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack continues huge growth, is now valued at $2.8 billion |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/4/16/8430039/slack-raises-160-million-valued-at-2-8-billion |date=April 16, 2015 |last=Welch |first=Chris |website=TheVerge.com |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> Late in 2015, Slack passed more than a million daily active users.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slack Keeps On Growing |url=http://www.technologyreview.com/view/538796/slack-keeps-on-growing/ |access-date=October 13, 2018 |first=Rachel |last=Metz |date=June 25, 2015 |website=[[MIT Technology Review]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Slack launches user groups, hits 1.7M daily active users and 470K paid seats |url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/10/29/slack-launches-user-groups-hits-1-7m-daily-active-users-and-470k-paid-seats/ |date=October 29, 2015 |first=Jordan |last=Novet |website=VentureBeat.com |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> {{As of|2018|05|}}, Slack had over 8 million daily users, 3 million of whom had paid accounts.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/5/22/17378228/slack-action-buttons-asana-jira-bitbucket-developer-conference |title=Slack adds action buttons to become a true workplace communication hub |last=Newton |first=Casey |date=May 22, 2018 |work=The Verge |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
The ''[[Financial Times]]'' wrote in March 2015 that Slack was the first business technology to have crossed from business into personal use since [[Microsoft Office]] and the [[BlackBerry]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/bd7dbf46-d24c-11e4-9c25-00144feab7de |title=Slack: workplace message app so cute you want to use it at home |newspaper=Financial Times |date=March 25, 2015 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}{{subscription required}}</ref> In 2017 a writer at [[New York (magazine)|''New York'']] magazine described it as "a compulsion, a distraction[, a] burden ... another utility we both rely on and resent".<ref>{{cite news |first=Molly |last=Fischer |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2017/05/what-has-slack-done-to-the-office.html |title=What Happens When Work Becomes a Nonstop Chat Room |newspaper=New York Magazine |date=May 17, 2017 |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
Slack was recognized as the best startup of the year 2017 at the 10th Crunchies Awards, organized by [[TechCrunch]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/02/06/and-the-winners-of-the-10th-annual-crunchies-are/ |title=And the winners of the 10th Annual Crunchies are… |first=Frederic |last=Lardinois |date=February 6, 2017 |publisher=[[TechCrunch]] |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
The digital rights group [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF) has cautioned that "Slack stores and is able to read all of your communications, as well as identifying information for everyone in your workspace".<ref name=":0">{{cite news |url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2018/02/revolution-and-slack |title=The Revolution and Slack |last=Cohn |first=Cindy |date=February 14, 2018 |work=Electronic Frontier Foundation |access-date=October 13, 2018 |last2=Gebhart |first2=Gennie |author-link=Cindy Cohn}}</ref> While commending the company for "follow[ing] several best practices in standing up for users" concerning government data requests, such as requiring a warrant for content stored on its server, and awarding it four out of five stars in its 2017 "Who has your back" report,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.eff.org/who-has-your-back-2017 |title=Who Has Your Back? Government Data Requests 2017 |date=July 10, 2017 |first=Rainey |last=Reitman |work=Electronic Frontier Foundation |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref> the EFF also criticized Slack for "a broad set of exceptions" to its promise to notify users of such requests, and for other privacy shortcomings.<ref name=":0" />
== Criticism == Slack has been criticized{{By whom|date=October 2018}} because the data is stored exclusively on [[cloud computing|cloud]] servers under Slack control.<ref name="slack-alternatives">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/03/open-source-devs-racing-build-better-versions-slack/ |title=Open sourcers race to build better versions of Slack |last=Finley |first=Klint |date=March 16, 2016 |website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref><ref name="uber">{{cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/uber-ditches-hipchat-slack-to-create-its-own-work-chat-app-uchat-2017-7 |title=Uber didn't like Silicon Valley's biggest chat apps — so it was forced to make its own |last=Peterson |first=Becky |date=July 26, 2017 |work=[[Business Insider]] |access-date=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
== Alternatives ==
=== Open source === There are a number of open source alternatives to Slack such as [[Mattermost]], [[Zulip]], [[Riot.im|Riot]] and [[Matrix_(protocol)|matrix]] that are free and can be [[Self-hosting#Website management|self-hosted]].<ref name="slack-alternatives" />
=== Proprietary === Other alternatives to Slack that follow a similar business model are [[Flock (messaging service)|Flock]] and Ryver. [[Microsoft Teams]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/3276276/collaboration/microsoft-teams-its-features-how-it-compares-to-slack-and-other-rivals.html |title=Microsoft Teams: Its features, how it compares to Slack and other rivals |last=Finnegan |first=Matthew |work=Computerworld |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=June 5, 2018}}</ref> Hangout Chats,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/02/28/google-hangouts-chat-slack-alternative-available/ |title=Google's Slack alternative is available starting today |work=Engadget |access-date=October 13, 2018 |date=February 28, 2018}}</ref> and tibber by Tibco.

[[File:Boeing 737 landing.jpg|thumb|Pilot workloads and stress increase during [[landing]] |253x253px]] '''Stress in the aviation industry''' is a common phenomenon composed of three sources: [[Physiology|physiological]] stressors, [[psychological]] stressors, and [[Environmental causes of aviation stress|environmental]] stressors.<ref name="how">{{cite web|last1=Hansen|first1=Fawne|title=How Do Airline Pilots Cope With Stress?|url=https://adrenalfatiguesolution.com/pilots-and-stress/|website=The Adrenal Fatigue Solution|publisher=Perfect Health|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref> Professional pilots can experience stress in flight, on the ground during work-related activities, and during personal time because of the influence of their occupation.<ref name=":0">Harris, Don, Professor. (2012). ''Human Performance on the Flight Deck''. Ashgate. Retrieved 1 December 2015, from <<nowiki>http://www.myilibrary.com?ID=317410</nowiki>></ref> An airline pilot can be an extremely stressful job due to the workload, responsibilities and safety of the thousands of passengers they transport around the world. Chronic levels of stress can negatively impact one's health, [[job performance]] and cognitive functioning.<ref name=":0" /> Being exposed to stress does not always negatively influence humans because it can motivate people to improve and help them adapt to a new environment.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jaret|first1=Peter|title=The Surprising Benefits Of Stress|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/the-surprising-benefits-of-stress_5626e8fee4b08589ef49a820|accessdate=18 November 2015|publisher=Huffpost Healthy Living|date=20 October 2015}}</ref> Unfortunate accidents start to occur when a pilot is under excessive stress, as it dramatically affects his or her physical, emotional, and mental conditions. Stress "jeopardizes decision-making relevance and cognitive functioning"<ref name="cognitive">{{cite journal|last1=Causse|first1=Mickaël|last2=Dehais|first2=Frédéric|title=The effects of emotion on pilot decision-making|journal=Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies|date=11 April 2012|volume=33|pages=272–281|doi=10.1016/j.trc.2012.04.005}}</ref> and it is a prominent cause of [[pilot error]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Learmount|first1=David|title=French research project highlights risk of pilot stress|url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/french-research-project-highlights-risk-of-pilot-stress-410078/|accessdate=28 November 2015|publisher=Flightglobal|date=12 March 2015}}</ref> Being a pilot is considered a unique job that requires managing high workloads and good psychological and physical health.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bor|first1=Robert|last2=Field|first2=Gary|last3=Scragg|first3=Peter|title=The mental health of pilots|journal=Counselling Psychology Quarterly|date=2002|volume=15|issue=3|pages=239–256|doi=10.1080/09515070210143471}}</ref> Unlike the other professional jobs, pilots are considered to be highly affected by stress levels. One study states that 70% of surgeons agreed that stress and [[Fatigue (safety)|fatigue]] don't impact their performance level, while only 26% of pilots denied that stress influences their performance.<ref name="Nicholas">{{cite journal|last1=Blouin|first1=Nicholas|last2=Richard|first2=Erin|last3=Deaton|first3=John|last4=Buza|first4=Paul|title=Effects of Stress on Perceived Performance of Collegiate Aviators|journal=Aviation Psychology and Applied Human Factors|date=2014|volume=4|pages=40–49|doi=10.1027/2192-0923/a000054}}</ref> Pilots themselves realize how powerful stress can be, and yet many accidents and incidents continues to occur and have occurred, such as [[Asiana Airlines Flight 214]], [[American Airlines Flight 1420]], and [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash#Stress and workload factors|Polish Air Force Tu-154]]
== Aviation accidents caused by stress == [[File:NTSBAsiana214TailWreckage.jpg|thumb|246x246px|[[Asiana Airlines Flight 214]] tail wreckage due to the crash]] [[Asiana Airlines Flight 214]] was one of many tragic accidents triggered by stress. It occurred on July 6, 2013 on the aircraft's final approach to [[San Francisco International Airport]] from [[Incheon International Airport]]. During its approach, the plane hit the edge of the runway and its tail came apart followed by the fuselage bursting into flames. The trainee pilot flying was "stressed about the approach to the unfamiliar airport and thought the autothrottle was working before the jet came in too low and too slow."<ref name =Asiana>{{cite journal|last1=Chow|first1=Stephanie|last2=Yortsos|first2=Stephen|last3=Meshkati|first3=Najmedin|title=Investigating Cockpit Automation and Culture Issues in Aviation Safety|journal=Aviation Psychology and Applied Human Factors|date=2014|volume=4|issue=2|pages=113–121|doi=10.1027/2192-0923/a000066}}</ref> He believed that the [[autothrottle]], which is designed to maintain speed, was always on. The trainee pilot should have had full understanding of his flight systems and high mode awareness, but he didn't. He told [[National Transportation Safety Board]] that he should have studied more. His inefficient knowledge of the flight deck automation and an unfamiliar airport structure caused excessive stress, and the aftermath was disastrous: three passengers died and more than 187 passengers were injured.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martinez|first1=Michael|title=A year later, survivors recall Asiana Flight 214 crash|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/07/06/us/california-asiana-plane-crash-anniversary/|accessdate=28 November 2015|publisher=CNN|date=6 July 2014}}</ref>
[[File:2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash 002.jpg|thumb|246x246px|[[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|Polish Air Force Tu-154]] crash site]] [[American Airlines Flight 1420]] took place on June 1, 1999. The pilot was Captain Richard Buschmann, considered an expert pilot with over ten thousand hours of flight time. The [[First officer (aeronautics)|First Officer]] was Michael Origel with under five thousand hours of flight time. The flight was set to land at the airport in Arkansas but a major thunderstorm was occurring in the area and Captain Buschmann decided to change runways due to the high crosswind and rapid change wind direction. The pilots were overcome with tasks and the stress of the difficult landing, forgetting to arm the automatic ground spoiler and ground braking systems.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/AAR0102.pdf|title = Runway Overrun During Landing American Airlines Flight 1420|date = June 1999|accessdate = |website = Aircraft Accident Report|publisher = National Transportation Safety Board|last = |first = }}</ref> It was too difficult to recover the aircraft and it slid off the runway and collided with a large steel walkway, resulting in the death of Captain Bucshmann and 10 passengers, with many suffering from severe injuries.
Another example is the [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash]] of April 2010, which killed Polish president [[Lech Kaczyński|Lech Kaczynski]]. During landing, the pilot Captain Arkadiusz Protasiuk was having difficulty landing due to severely foggy conditions, but the number of high-status passengers and priority of arriving on time pressured him onwards. Captain Protasiuk brought the aircraft down through the clouds at too low of an altitude, resulting in a [[controlled flight into terrain]]. His attempt to land failed and the plane crashed into a forest, killing the crew and all the passengers. Further study by the [[Interstate Aviation Committee]] regarding the cockpits voice recordings revealed that there was never a direct command for the pilot to go through with the landing, but the report did show that the pilot was under a "cascade of stress much of it emanating from his powerful passengers, as Captain Protasiuk slipped below the decision altitude".<ref>{{cite news|title = Polish Crash’s Causes: Pilot Error and Stress, Report Says|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/13/world/europe/13crash.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2011-01-12|access-date = 2015-12-02|issn = 0362-4331|first = Ellen|last = Barry}}</ref> This accident led to the death of 96 people, all due to the high amount of stress being put on the pilot, affecting his mental state, inhibiting him from doing his job.
=== Advances In cockpit technology === From the [[Asiana Airlines Flight 214]] study, Kathy Abbott of the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] stated that "the data suggests that the highly integrated nature of current flight decks and additional add-on features have increased flight crew knowledge and introduced complexity that sometimes results in pilot confusion and errors during flight deck operation."<ref name =Asiana /> U.S. investigators instructed the manufactures to fix Boeing 777's complex control systems because pilots "no longer fully understand" how aircraft systems works.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Withnall|first1=Adam|title=Asiana Airlines flight 214 crash caused by Boeing planes being 'overly complicated'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/asiana-airlines-flight-214-crash-caused-by-boeing-planes-being-overly-complicated-9562331.html|accessdate=28 November 2015|publisher=Independent|date=25 June 2014}}</ref> As technology advances, more and more new instruments are put into the cockpit panel. As these increase, cognitive demands also increase, and pilots are becoming distracted from their primary tasks.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leung|first1=Ying|last2=Morris|first2=Charles|title=Pilot mental workload: how well do pilots really perform|journal=Ergonomics|date=15 December 2006|volume=49|issue=15|pages=1581–1596|pmid=17090505|doi=10.1080/00140130600857987}}</ref> Although having various types of information enhances [[situation awareness]], it also overloads sensory channels.<ref name= "cite" /> Since human's cognitive loads are limited, information overloads only increase the risk of flight accidents. Pilots have more difficulty perceiving and processing the data when information are overwhelming.<ref name="blood" />
== Effects on memory == [[File:Working memory model.svg|left|thumb|209x209px|Model of [[working memory]]]] There are three components of memory: [[Long-term memory|long-term]], [[Short-term memory|short-term]], and [[working memory]]. When stress kicks in, a pilot’s working memory is impaired. Stress either limits the amount of resources that can be accessed through working memory or the time which these sources can be accessed are inhibited.<ref name="Nicholas" /> When a pilot feels stressed, he or she will notice an increase in heart rate, higher blood pressure, muscle tensions, anxiety and fatigue.<ref name="blood">{{cite journal|last1=Keränen|first1=Heikki|last2=Huttunen|first2=Kerttu|last3=Väyrynen|first3=Eero|title=Effect of cognitive load on speech prosody in aviation|journal=Applied Ergonomics|date=17 August 2010|volume=42|issue=2|pages=348–357|pmid=20832770|doi=10.1016/j.apergo.2010.08.005}}</ref> These physiological stress symptoms eventually interrupt the pilot’s cognitive functions by reducing his or her memory capacity and restraining cue samples. Through a study researchers found that stress greatly affects flight performances including, smoothness and accuracy of landing, ability to multi-task, and being ahead of the plane.<ref name="Nicholas" /> Further research shows that under high stress, people are likely to make the same decision he or she has previously made, whether or not it led to a positive or a negative consequence before.<ref name="Nicholas" />
== Causes of stress == Stress can be caused by [[Environmental causes of aviation stress|environmental]], [[Physiology|physiological]], or [[psychological]] factors. Environmental stress can be caused by loud noise, small cockpit space, temperature, or any factors affecting one physically via one's current surroundings.<ref name="how" /> Unpleasant environments can raise one's stress level. Physiological stress is a physical change due to influence of fatigue, anxiety, hunger, or any factors that may change a pilot's biological rhythms.<ref name="s">{{cite web|title=The effects of stress on pilot performance|url=http://www.pilotfriend.com/training/flight_training/human/stress.htm|website=Human Factor in Aviation|publisher=Pilotfriend|accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref> Lastly, psychological factors include personal issues, including experiences, mental health, relationships and any other emotional issues a pilot may face.<ref name="s" /> All these stressors interfere with cognitive activity and limit a pilot's ability to achieve peak performance. It is important to minimize these possible sources of stress to maximize pilots' cognitive loads, which affects their perception, memory, and logical reasoning.<ref name= "cite">{{cite journal|last1=Hancock|last2=Weaver|title=On time distortion under stress|journal=Theoretical Issues in Ergonomics Science|date=April 2005|volume=6|issue=2|pages=193–211|doi=10.1080/14639220512331325747}}</ref>
== Stress in flight == [[File:Inverted u.jpg|thumb|227x227px| [[Yerkes–Dodson law]] shows that too low or too high arousal results in low performance]]
Researchers found that improvements in technology have significantly reduced aviation accidents, but [[human error]] still endangers flight safety. An individual reacts to stress in different ways, depending on how one perceives stress.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kowalski-Trakofler|first1=Kathleen|last2=Vaught|first2=Charles|title=Judgment and decision making under stress: an overview for emergency managers|journal=Int. J. Emergency Management|date=2003|volume=1|issue=3|pages=278–289|doi=10.1504/ijem.2003.003297}}</ref> If an individual judges that he or she has resources to cope with demands of the situation, it will be evaluated as a challenge. On the other hand, if an individual believes situational demands outweigh the resources, he or she will evaluate it as a [[threat]], leading to poorer performance. Under the threat response, researchers stated that pilots became more distracted with their controls and had higher tendencies to scan unnecessary instruments.<ref name="stress">{{cite journal|last1=Vine|first1=Samuel|last2=Uiga|first2=Liis|last3=Lavric|first3=Aureliu|last4=Moore|first4=Lee|last5=Tsaneva-Atanasova|first5=Krasimira|last6=Mark|first6=Wilson|title=Individual reactions to stress predict performance during a critical aviation incident|journal=Anxiety, Stress, & Coping|date=2015|volume=28|issue=4|pages=467–477|doi=10.1080/10615806.2014.986722}}</ref>
Plan Continuation Error (PCE) is one of the types of decision-making error pilot conducts. PCE is defined as an "erroneous behavior due to failure to revise a flight plan despite emerging evidence that suggests it is no longer safe."<ref name="cognitive" /> The [[French Land Transport Accident Investigation Bureau]] (BEA) stated that 41.5% of casualties in general aviation were caused by get-home-itis syndrome; which happens when a pilot intents to land at the planned destination, no matter what it takes.<ref name="cognitive" /> A pilot must use their own judgment to go-around whenever it is necessary, but he or she often fails to do so. Through the study, it was found that mental workload of stress and heart rate increases when making go-around decisions. A pilot feels pressured and stressed by the obligation to get passengers to their destinations at the right time and to continue the flight as planned. When choosing between productivity and safety, pilots' risk assessments can be influenced unconsciously. [[American Airlines Flight 1420]] accidents was one example caused by PCE; although the flight crew knew it was dangerous to continue the flight as severe thunderstorms was approaching, they continued on with their flight.
=== Positive and negative views of stress === Stress can narrow the focus of attention in a good way and in a bad way. Stress helps to simplify a pilot's task and enables him or her to focus on major issues by eliminating nonessential information.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Maureen|title=Can stress ever be good for wellbeing?|url=http://www.actionforhappiness.org/news/can-stress-ever-be-good-for-wellbeing|accessdate=28 November 2015|publisher=Action For Happiness|date=18 November 2014}}</ref> In other words, a pilot can simplify information and react accordingly to major [[Sensory cue|cues]] only. However, when a pilot exceeds his or her cognitive load, it will eventually narrow his or her attention too much and cause inattentiaon deafness.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tracking pilots’ brains to reduce risk of human error|url=http://www.euronews.com/2015/05/26/tracking-pilots-brains-to-reduce-risk-of-human-error/|accessdate=28 November 2015|publisher=Euronews|date=26 May 2015}}</ref> The pilot will mainly focus on doing the primary task and ignore secondary tasks, such as audible alarms and spoken instructions.
== Military pilot stress == Military pilots experience a more fast-paced and stressful career compared to airline and general aviation pilots. Military pilots experience significantly greater stress levels due to significant reliability and performance expectations.<ref>Ahmadi, K., & Alireza, K. (2007). Stress and Job Satisfaction among Air Force Military Pilots.''Journal of Social Sciences,'' ''3''(3), 159-163. Retrieved November 17, 2015, from http://docsdrive.com/pdfs/sciencepublications/jssp/2007/159-163.pdf</ref> They hold a unique position in the workforce that includes peak physical and mental condition, high intelligence and extensive training. All military pilots, at times, must work under extreme conditions, experiencing high levels of stress, especially in a war zone. Soldiers are made to endure punishment and go through the most unthinkable situations. They are expected to continue with their job and at times completely ignore their own emotions. After initial training, the military completely reforms the individual, and in most cases incredible stress management skills are formed. The soldier is then sent off for further training, in this case to be a pilot, where they are tested and challenge even further to either fail or become one of the best.
Military pilots withhold a lot of responsibility. Their jobs can include passenger or cargo transport, reconnaissance missions, or attacking from the air or flight training, all while expected to be in perfect mental and physical condition. These job place a responsibility on the pilot to avoid mistakes as millions of dollars, lives, or whole operations are at risk. At times stress does over take the pilot<ref>{{cite journal|url = https://www.familyforce.ca/sites/Valcartier/SiteCollectionDocuments/Guide-BSO_ANG.pdf|title = Signs of Operational Stress Injury|last = Kholer|first = Nadia|date = 2012|publisher= Valcartier Family Medical Centre|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> and emotions and human error can occur. [[File:JAS-39 Gripen (CzAF) February 2014.jpg|thumb|Military fighter jet JAS-39 Gripen|left|240x240px]] There are countless occurrences of pilots bombing allied forces in [[List of friendly fire incidents|friendly fire incidents]] out of error and having to live with the consequences.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
The stress of the job itself or of any mistake made can hugely affect one's life outside work. Millions of veterans struggle with [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress injuries]], unhealthy coping strategies such as alcohol or substance abuse<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://pubs.niaaa.nih.gov/publications/arcr344/toc34_4.htm|title = Alcohol and Stress in the Military|last = Schumm|first = Jeremiah. A|date = 2004|journal = Military Trauma and Stress Related Disorders|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> and in the worst of cases, suicide, which is very common. Many studies and help programs<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/doi/abs/10.1176/appi.ajp.162.9.1688|title = Suicide Among Regular-Duty Military Personnel: A Retrospective Case-Control Study of Occupation-Specific Risk Factors for Workplace Suicide|last = Mahon|first = Martin. J.|date = 2005|journal = American Journal of Psychiatry|volume=162 |issue=9 |pages=1688–1696 |doi =10.1176/appi.ajp.162.9.1688 |pmid = 16135629|access-date = }}</ref> have been put in place, but there are many different cases and people that it is impossible to help everyone. Stress overcomes even the strongest, most highly training pilots and can take the worst toll.
Everyone deals with stress in a different manner, but military pilots stand out on their own with unique stress reducing and problem solving skills. Their main strategy is to find the problem causing the stress and solve it immediately<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/617762395|title = An empirical assessment of stress-coping styles in military pilots.|last = Picano|first = James. J.|date = 1990|journal = Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine |volume=61 |issue=4 |pages=356–360|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> so that they do not have to move to a secondary option, which consumes time they do not have. This is what they are taught in flight school; a sensor goes off and they immediately fix the problem. The main problem appears when pilots are going high speed or undergoing complicated maneuvers.<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/26272972|title = Investigation of the specific workability of the military pilots in the hypergravitational stress.|last = Pandov, Dimitrov, Popandreeva|first = |date = 1996|journal = International Congress of Aviation and Space Medicine, 44th, Jerusalem, Israe|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Most times they are moving much faster than a human could even think, leaving a lot of room for human error. When that error occurs, however big or small, they can take on immense guilt for any problems that were caused depending on their personality.<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/622124959|title = Personality profiles and stress-coping strategies of slovenian military pilots|last = Meško|first = Maja|date = 2009|journal = Psihološka Obzorja / Horizons of Psychology |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=23–38|doi = |pmid = |access-date = October 20, 2015}}</ref> This can affect their mental state<ref>Kemmler, R. W. 1981. Psychological therapy and prevention of stress reactions in german military pilots. ''AGARD The Effect of Long-Term Therap., Prophylaxis and Screening Tech.on Aircrew Med.Standards 11 p (SEE N81-26699 17-52); International Organization'', http://search.proquest.com/docview/23808327 (accessed October 28, 2015).</ref> and ability to continue their job. Stress can also take a physical toll on a pilot's body, such as grinding of their teeth<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://search.proquest.com/docview/621625653|title = Bruxism in military pilots and non-pilots: Tooth wear and psychological stress.|last = Lurie, Yehuda, Einy, Terracsh, Raviv, Goldstein|first = |date = 2007|journal = Aviation, Space, and Environmental Medicine |volume=78 |issue=2 |pages=137–139|doi = |pmid = |access-date = October 19, 2015}}</ref> in difficult situations or even bladder problems when the pilot is flying with a higher [[G-force]] or for a long distance.<ref>Ohrui, Nobuhiro, Fumiko Kanazawa, Yoshinori Takeuchi, Yasutami Otsuka, Hideo Tarui, and Yoshinori Miyamoto. 2008. Urinary catecholamine responses in F-15 pilots: Evaluation of the stress induced by long-distance flights. ''Military medicine'' 173, (6): 594-598, http://search.proquest.com/docview/622029080 (accessed October 26, 2015).</ref>
== Improvements through crew resource management == After the 1950s, [[human error]] became the main cause of aviation accidents.<ref name= "CRM" /> Stress and fatigue continues to be an issue in the aviation industry. Hence, various training are being conducted to minimize it. The change began as [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] pointed out human limitations and emphasized the importance of teamwork.<ref name= "CRM">{{cite journal|last1=Sexton|first1=Bryan|last2=Thomas|first2=Eric|last3=Helmreich|first3=Robert|title=Error, Stress, and Teamwork in Medicine and Aviation: Cross Sectional Surveys|journal=British Medical Journal|date=18 Mar 2000|volume=320|issue=7237|pages=745–749|pmid=10720356|pmc=27316|doi=10.1136/bmj.320.7237.745}}</ref> [[Crew Resource Management]] is a type of training conducted to teach a flight crew different behavioral strategies, such as situational awareness, stress management, and decision-making.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wilhelm|first1=John|last2=Merritt|first2=Ashleigh|last3=Helmreich|first3=Robert|title=The Evolution of Crew Resource Management Training in Commercial Aviation|date=January 1999|volume=9|issue=1|pages=19–32}}</ref> When pilots are being hired, recruiters not only look at pilots' technical skills, but also at pilots' ability to learn from errors and evaluate how well they coordinate with other crew members.
== See also == * [[Environmental causes of aviation stress|Environmental stress]] * [[Pilot error]] * [[Air safety#Human factors|Human factors in air safety]] * [[Human reliability]] * [[Airmanship]] * [[Aviation accidents and incidents|Aviation accidents]] * [[Aviation Safety Network]]

{{for|the ship|Treasurer (warship)}} [[Image:National-Debt-Gillray.jpeg|thumb|In ''A new way to pay the National Debt'' (1786), [[James Gillray]] caricatured [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Queen Charlotte]] and [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III]] awash with treasury funds to cover royal debts, with [[William Pitt the Younger|Pitt]] handing them another moneybag.]] A '''treasurer''' is the person responsible for running the [[treasury]] of an organization. The adjective for a treasurer is normally "tresorial." The adjective "treasurial" normally means pertaining to a treasury, rather than the treasurer. The significant core functions of a corporate treasurer include cash and liquidity management, risk management, and corporate finance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.treasury-management.com/showarticle.php?pubid=4&issueid=121&article=1053&page=showarticle&pageno=1|title=The Functions of a Corporate Treasury|last=Degenhart|first=Dr. Heinrich|date=|website=www.treasury-management.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-05}}</ref>
==Government== {{see also|State treasurer}} The [[treasury]] of a country is the department responsible for the country's [[economy]], [[finance]] and [[revenue]]. The treasurer is generally the head of the Treasury, although, in some countries (such as the United Kingdom or the United States) the treasurer reports to a [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Secretary of the Treasury]] or [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]]. In [[Australia]], the [[Treasurer of Australia|Treasurer]] is a senior [[Minister (government)|Minister]] and usually the second most important member of the [[Executive (government)|Government]] after the [[Prime Minister]].
From 1867 to 1993, [[Ministry of Finance (Ontario)|Ontario's Minister of Finance]] was called the Treasurer of Ontario.
Originally the word referred to the person in charge of the [[treasure]] of a [[nobility|noble]]; however, it has now moved into wider use. In the UK during the 17th Century, a position of [[Lord High Treasurer]] was used on several occasions as the third great officer of [[the Crown]]. Now the title [[First Lord of the Treasury]] is the official title of the British [[Prime Minister]].
==In the Inns of Court== In the [[Inns of Court]], the professional associations for [[barristers in England and Wales|barristers]] in [[England]] and [[Wales]], the ''[[bencher]]'' or ''Master of the bench'' who heads the Inn for that year holds the title 'Master Treasurer'. This title is similarly used by other legal associations sharing a British heritage, such as the [[Law Society of Upper Canada]].
== Volunteer organizations == Many volunteer organizations, particularly [[not-for-profit]] organizations such as [[charities]] and [[theaters]], appoint treasurers who are responsible for conservation of the treasury, whether this be through pricing of a product, organizing [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsorship]], or arranging fundraising events.
The treasurer would also be part of the group which would oversee how the money is spent, either directly dictating expenditure or authorizing it as required. It is their responsibility to ensure that the organization has enough money to carry out their stated aims and objectives, and that they do not overspend, or under spend. They also report to the board meetings and/or to the general membership the financial status of the organization to ensure checks and balances.<ref>{{Cite book|title = [[Robert's Rules of Order]] Newly Revised|last = Robert|first = Henry M.|publisher = Da Capo Press|year = 2011|isbn = 978-0-306-82020-5|location = Philadelphia, PA|pages = 461, 477-480|edition = 11th|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Accurate records and supporting documentation must be kept to a reasonable level of detail that provides a clear audit trail for all transactions.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Robert's Rules of Order Newly Revised In Brief|last = Robert III|first = Henry M.|publisher = Da Capo Press|year = 2011|isbn = 978-0-306-82019-9|location = Philadelphia, PA|pages = 153-155|edition = 2nd|url = http://www.robertsrules.com/inbrief.html|display-authors=etal}}</ref>

'''Veterinary equivalency''' is the mutual recognition by two or more countries that each party’s safety and sanitation standards for animal products, even where not identical, provide an equivalent level of protection to [[Public health|public]] and [[Veterinary medicine|animal health]]. Aimed at facilitating trade, the practical effect of veterinary equivalency is that each country’s individual products and facilities will not have to submit to the separate standards of importing countries and to cumbersome and costly inspections by foreign reviewers.
Veterinary equivalency has been a contentious issue for the [[United States]] and [[European Union]] (EU). The two parties in 1997 agreed in principle to an agreement recognizing each other’s standards, but did not sign the agreement until July 1999 due to a series of unresolved technical disputes. Some parts of this agreement remained in dispute in 2002.
